reviewText:
Sifting through the reviews you will find that many negative reviews are due to the always online DRM or episodic format.
While I don't favor either one of these, I can see from a developer's standpoint why they are implemented: no pirating and the ability to charge full price for a game during a time period where other games would have dropped in price.
Sure the business model may suck" from a gamer perspective but should not alone be responsible for the verdict on the game.

The game itself (one episode released) is in my honest opinion really fun. I have played Hitman games since the beginning and "Blood money" is by far my favorite. This title brings back the sandbox elements of "Blood money" but with updated graphics and gameplay.

I had no problem running Hitman on Ultra (GTX 970)
date: but decreased the settings a tad to ensure that it ran smoothly
recommended:
which it really does! (Unless you are disconnected from the servers and have to restart from the lobby).
The visuals are not "spectacular" but still really good.

There's high replayability of the missions. I've played 18 hours on two tutorial levels and the one mission level when writing this and am now eagerly awaiting the next episode.
To be honest
hoursPlayed: the episodic format kind of forces you to replay the same missions. However
voteText: this is in my opinion quite nice as I don't feel stressed to just quickly complete a mission. There's actually time to really enjoy and master each level this way.\nAlso
helpfulPercent: it feels very good to know that there are plenty of missions to come as the game is already really fun. For me the release of every episode will have a hype factor to it.\n\nThe AI is not the best
votesHelpful: but I don't expect that from Hitman games. It is true that you cannot change difficulty settings and this might seem like a bummer
votesTotal: but from what I've played so far I feel it is balanced. It still requires skill to do a "Silent assassin + Suit only" run perfectly.\n\nDefault key bindings are a mess
votesFunny:
but they are customizable so that's fine.

Verdict:
I understand if you want to dismiss this game due to the questionable business model
commentsCount: but if you like Hitman games please don't. If you are not keen on waiting for episodes
column16: wait until full release.\nThis game is really fun and does not deserve the mixed review stats. If you doubt it
column17: buy the intro pack and judge it yourself. I'm glad that I bought the full experience and within a couple of episodes I'm sure I will feel like the price was justified."

reviewText:
I never write reviews.

If there was one game I was looking forward to it was this one.

Square Enix & IO Interactive have really missed the mark.

I'm a long time hitman fan. It absolutley kills me that I had to request a refund for this game due to the developer's elitist attitude and unwillingness to address the community's overwhelming  gameplay issues and techincal problems.

Now the small level to level experience of Absolution wasn't the greatest, but at least I was able to actually play it at a stable 60fps. This game however has perhaps the poorest optimization I've seen in recent years.

I have:

I5 3rd Gen
Nvida 760TI
8gb Ram

Not the most powerful system, but I can play Hitman Absolution, Grand Theft Auto V, Max Payne 3, on VERY HIGH settings and get a smooth 60 FPS in 1080p.

To give you an idea of how ridiculous the PC optimization for this game is, I can't even get a smooth gameplay experience ON LOW Settings at 1280p resolution!

It doesn't matter if you have an Nvida - AMD, I5 - I7, Direct X 11 - Direct X 12- You are GUARANTEED to run into frame rate dips and crashes unless you are running the best of the best.

In addition to immersion breaking technical issues, you also have clueless developers that refuse to face the facts , own up to their mistakes, and most importanly, FIX THEM!

Here are some of the many issues people are complaining about, and rightly so :

- One episode released per month. You have to wait until 2017 to have all the levels.
- Releasing un-tested updates that further break the game and don't fix current issues
- Terrible gameplay optimization issues that render the experience unplayable for many, including myself.
- Forcing you online for no plausible reason. Achievements are only available in online mode.
- If you lose your connection to their server in the middle of a mission, you're immediately sent back to the menu without a chance to save your progress to re-connect".
- You can play in offline mode
date: but many game types are not available and Online and Offline saves are not compatiable!\n- The autosaving feature
recommended: which turns on when you're about do any sort of action (approach a NPC
hoursPlayed: execute a task etc) causes a stutter each time it runs.\n\nYou may notice that i did play this game for 27 hours. The first level
voteText: though far from a smooth experience
helpfulPercent: was still playable. With the release of the second episode however
votesHelpful: the game is now compleltey unplayable.\n\nWhat makes this such a shame is that the big open levels are back
votesTotal: the npc Ai is better (but not perfect) and with the release of the second episode; Sapienza
votesFunny: there are some great visuals.\n\nAll in all
commentsCount: do yourself a favor and miss this purchase
column16: at least for now. Hopefully the developer will get their ♥♥♥♥ together and properly optimize this game
column17: however I've given up on that hope after 3 months and countless updates."

reviewText:
The good...
A.  Well put together and more blood money style than anyother hitman (I have really disliked all other takes on this game other than blood money and this one).
B.  Visually pleasing.  I run this on max settings and its nice.  Not sure why there is an in game benchmarking tool for this as it really isnt that impressive, but still very nice.
C.  Depending on your mark this can be very challenging depending on your mission requirments or personal goals.  This would not be a good game without challenge and once you start playing around a little there are some pretty cool/funny kills like drowning a mark in the toilet (super duper swirley) or killing one target with the falling body of another target.
D.  My favorite feature, the community created hits.  I did little to no reserch on this game and only watched a bit of gameplay before buying as I had pretty much written this series of games off years ago.  But really this hitman sandbox thing they have going is pretty cool.  It keeps the game fresh and fully allows you to approach a target to the best of your abilities making this a more open experience in comparison the the story.

The bad...
A.  One of the most counter intuitive key command systems I've played in a long while.  Im not sure why the devs couldn't figure out how to make one key do multiple things such as hold shift to run and also hold shift to slide down a ladder faster.  In this game shift is run and holding S and X is slide down.  Its wierd, thats not the only thing, but its an example.
B.  The way the game is layed out for payment.  Its has kind of a rip off feel to it.  Look it up but in short you pay an initial price for the game" and then more money for "levels"...and it really was released with only one level as in my opinion the tutorial does not count.
C.  The sniper
hoursPlayed:
and shotgun all look incredibly stupid.  Larger than they should be and... purple.  I mean really purple!  I wanted to be a cold blooded hitman and you gave me PURPLE GUNS !?!?!?!?!?!  I dont want to get my account in a bind but read into that.  That really is upsetting and I wonder who in that dev team made that call or maybe it was the janitor that snuck into the game files late one night and set the color to purple and increased the size by +50%.

The inbetween...
A.  The one level launch.  This in my opinion is mostly bad but the positive part of it is since there is only one "sandbox" area
voteText: the percieved lack of content issue subsides when you realize how much there is to do in that one place.  The menus are a little funky on the home screen but throw 10 minutes at looking at everything and then do some of that stuff.  Once you realize how much there is going on the saltyness of what you thought you purchased goes away as you realize what content is actually there.\nB.  Unlocks.  The weapons are NOT very unrewarding to unlock.  You feel no more powerfull than you did before unlocking them.  They missed the mark for sure there
helpfulPercent: but the unlocks for inserting into different areas with disguises already on was suprisingly good...not like a bad ♥♥♥ weapon...but still good.\n\nAgain I wish steam had a rating that was middle of the road but I will give this one a thumbs up but really do your reserch.  Look at gameplay

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the Hitman franchise for a fairly long time now. This is the best hitman game I've experienced yet though.

If you're considering to buy this game, here are some of my thoughts:

Bad:

Crashes - Frequently (can be annoying as you've spent many hours doing a mission with hard work to see it crash after)
FPS - Dropping and Raising every now and then.

Glitchy - When dragging body's, this may be a bit glitchy if you're moving them from a chair as the character's body your dragging starts shaking. Sometimes if someone has long hair and you hide their body inside a closet for an example, their hair may come out of the closet, please fix this!

Always Online - This can be very, very annoying. This constributes to the part where if your internet shuts down for a second, your whole entire game will crash and progress will be lost. But at the same time, I do understand why they do this (to stop people pirating the game)

Blood: I realized that the character's you kill don't really have blood animations, please add blood animations to make the game even one step closer to realism.

Episodes - Episodes are being released monthly which can be very annoying. This doesn't really put much of an effect on me as the first episode is very hard to complete. Even if I did complete it, I would be doing the different methods of the killing.

Good:

Graphics - The graphics on this game are unbelievebly good, I don't know how they're going to be able to make another Hitman game with graphics this good!

Killing - When killing people (e.g with a fire axe, wrench, etc.) the animations are quite realistic.

Blood Puddles - When you've killed a person, a blood puddle is created underneath them, but it's a shame you can't actually see blood animations.

There are a lot more good things, but I can't really explain all of it in this little review.

Overall, I would most surely recommend HITMAN for killing game lovers. I'd also recommend getting the Full Experience instead of the Intro Pack as there are a lot more fun missions that you will be missing out on if you don't get it.

reviewText:
Okay, here are my thoughts of the game... Being a long time fan of hitman series, my personal best were Hitman Contracts and Blood Money... The thing that hurt me the most with this game is terrible performance ;/ I dont mind always online design... After doing some research and looking through game files i have worked out that this game is really CPU intensive i had to buy myself liquid CPU cooler to actually stop my CPU from throtling and keep stable FPS in this game at my OC of 4.1hz on fx 8320.

Pros:
Big maps.
Freedom of aproach.
Loads of equipement to unlock.
Contracts and bloodmonay like feeling while playing.

Cons:
CPU intensive game at its core ;/ + Denuvo DRM which is CPU killer... Bad move from IO Interactive here as that DRM might have just killed the game for them... as it is inpossible to maintain 60FPS in this game without i7 series processor overclocked to 5Ghz.

Would i recomend this game to a friend ?
Well if you can invest in water cooling and have an amd CPU with at least 8 cores overclocked to 4.2Ghz and you dont mind 30fps with dips to 25 on highest settings. Then yes ;p Otherwise no.... As far as im concerned intel cpus are a bit better off in this game ;p although not a lot.

reviewText:
This pre/review might get updated along the way to reflect more of the gameplay, bugs and what not.

I was about to make a pass on this game, partially due to the negative reviews (which doesn't detail the bugs nearly as good as some of the positives) but mostly because I'm on a 2core CPU with the minimum recommended specs having a 4core. In other games that are more CPU than GPU heavy I really feel the boundaries of my 2 cores >.<

Please note that I haven't tried the first mission yet, Paris, and I've only been fiddling around in the tutorial so far - But what a time it's been. Not only am I having fun, but the game is awesome to look at. It runs smoothly, and there are multiple ways to complete and approach an objective. It's filled with challenges which helps on the replayability a bit, for those of us who aren't die hard Hitman fans - I'm not one for sure :)

The big elephant in the room: DRM and Episodes.
I really don't mind the DRM in this case, for one reason only. My internet is stable. For people in rural areas, on shoddy connections or something similar, I could imagine this being a big deal breaker. I haven't tried the offline mode yet, mainly since I've read it's so crippled" compared to the online one (Saved checkpoints/games aren't compatible
date: some modes/achievements/challenges are limited or even disabled).\n\nAbout the episodes... *shrugs* I knew it

reviewText:
If you were disappointed by Hitman:Absolution since it was just an average stealth game and really wanted the great Hitman gameplay back, the big levels where you have to explore and find one of the many ways to kill your target, then get this game.
It has everything the hitman fans wanted since Blood Money and the levels are bigger, prettier and more complex than ever. Don't get turned off by the fact that the final game only features 7 levels, because the levels are really big. Playing them again to find all the different way to kill and approach your target offers quite some content next to extra challenges and contracts.

The episodic release even gives you the option to just test a small part of the game for a small price and then you can still decide if the game lives up to the name and buy the rest.

The only big complain I have about the game is the always online DRM. Now you can play with no connection but that doesn't save any progress.
A singleplayer game absolutly should not demand a connection to the internet and I hope this will be changed. What if the server go down or your internet craps out? That means getting kicked out of the game.
I never had any issues with the connection though so I don't mind it that much and if you don't have a problem with it either then I highly recommend getting Hitman.

reviewText:
Hitman may have been a great game, yet poor design choices and always-online drm garrotes Agent 47 and leaves this game gurgling in the toilet.

What's Good:

Our first map offering, Paris, is quite detailed and a large playground of murder. I have no issue with the new design being centered around repeating this large map with varying objectives. It's fun trying to complete escalations as the mission difficulty slowly increases. I used to play Blood Money in the same way, completing a mission and then trying a new angle. So it's cool that they've built this in with their unlock and challenge system.

Kills are satisfying in that there appear to be multiple options. There are some of the bigger more staged options and I would recommend turning off the Opportunities hints as they basically hold your hand. Beyond that though it's fun turning people chaotic so you can sneak up behind someone and stab them with a lethal injection. The core of the game (map design, ai, sound, visuals) is great.

What's not good:

I'm always amazed how developers can create something good and then shoot themselves in their own foot. I don't play Hitman for multiplayer. Leaderboards are why the game has always-on drm. And it's felt. On my final part of an escalation mission, I was disconnected randomly and bounced back to the main menu. This negated all the work I had just done. To have my play interrupted by a feature that I care nothing about in a game that isnt about other people is beyond infuriating. I appreaciate them trying to tap into community content with the contracts feature. But we don't need always on drm for that.

Also the episodic release schedule is confusing for a hitman game. The story isn't compelling enough for me to WANT to see what happens next. Which has to be the case for Episodic release to work. Instead you walk away feeling like you have a very small repetitive game.

BOTTOMLINE:
Core mechanics are great but the game is hampered by always on drm and episodic release schedule. Not enough content to keep you motivated to continue playing.

reviewText:
This game is actually really good. Most people seem to want to hate the game because of having to be always online and the fact that it is being released in an episodic format. Does it suck having to be always online to be able to play a single player game? Sure. The fact of the matter is that some people, much like myself, are always online anyways so this affects me, in what I feel,  such a small way. As for the game being episodic, Square has made it abundantly clear that it was going to have this type of release, so I'm surpised (and also not surprised) that many people who write reviews use this as a negative. You purchased the game knowing what it was going to be like and if you don't enjoy, then refund it.

As for gameplay I would just like to give a few pros and cons that I have noticed in my small amount of play time.

Pros:

- Extremely open and the level provides a variety of ways to complete it.

- Actions seem to be a lot faster in this one. Dumping a body in a dumpster for instance, you don't have to watch the whole scene.

- The people who stand around a level/the scenery really makes the game atmospherically amuzing.


Cons:

- I heard that the game has slow load times, though on an SSD, this is not an issue.

- The game does not run very well. I have a 980ti/i7 4770k and I had to turn down a lot of options to get a steady 60 frames per second.

- The game crashes sometimes. I have only experienced this twice and luckily it was resolved by using DX11 instead of DX12. I can definitely see how this would turn someone off of the game.

That's about all that I can notice so far. I look forward to more levels being released because by the way it's looking, it is going to be WAY more like Blood Money than Absolution....which is like, what everyone wanted in a new Hitman game, right?

reviewText:
Do not listen to those who are giving negative reviews. I took the time to read a majority of them and the only problem they seem to have is connection issues. I have yet to have one connection issue with my game.

Since that is the case, I must spend my criticism on the actual gameplay. This game is immense! I cannot find a better word to describe it. Only one mission, but 1000 ways to complete it. I spent most of my time completing challenges and discovering new ways to lure, expose, or kill my targets. This element was prevelant in Blood Money but absent in Absolution. Glad the developers took the time to recognize that and bring it back into the world of assassination. It took me about 4 hours to finally achieve Silent Assassin with only wearing the suit. Talk about difficult.
For those who enjoy the difficulty of playing Hitman, take off all the indicators, instinct, mini-map. It makes it that much harder. Also  try avoiding the use of any guides, for it will only decrease the enjoyment. I would also like to say that if you are a perfectionist, then get ready to hit that restart, save, and load buttons multiple times. The Showstopper mission in Paris is full of obstacles that need to be conquered. The AI is very sensitive to small movements, sounds, and any altercations 47 has with other people. If your goal is to kill someone other than your targets, then by all means do so. Just know that if you don't hide the bodies there will be consequences.
Lastly, I would like to talk about the mechanics of the game. If you are thinking about doing something with an object, then you can do it. Name an object: knife, screwdriver, wrench, lead pipe, scissors, fire axe, remote controlled explosive device with detonator. Take these items and do what you please with them. The environment allows you to do what you please. You can shoot the chain off a chandalier and it will fall and crash. Shoot a fire extinguisher and it will explode. The possibilities are endless. 30 hours into the game and hoping to double it when more missions come out. The episodic development is a good idea for one reason. If you don't like the game, then you would only be screwed out of $15. You can buy the intro pack and see what the game is like. If you enjoy it, then buy the upgraded version for another $49.99. The devs were smart in doing this because there are some people who have not been die hard Hitman fans like myself. This type of game needs an aquired taste and loads of patience. If you cannot take your time to complete a mission, then do not bother with this game. Go back to your Call of Duty.

Pros
-Unlimited ways to approach and terminate your targets
-Immense environment to wander and lurk around
-AI is very intelligent and have a variety of conversations
-Sound is realistic (gun fire, glass breaking, etc.)
-Gameplay is fluid and not mechanical
-An array of challenges to complete (assassinations, discovery, feats)
-Stealth and Aggression are both welcomed
-Options to turn on or off indicators for assisstance
-Pools of blood and blood splatter on walls
-Sandbox style game

Cons
-Graphics could be better
-No multiplayer
-Aim down sight is hard to get used to
-Guards will shoot you if you do not comply
-No rifle case for the sniper
-POV is awkward (over the right and left shoulder view, it should be centered)
-No first person point of view (it was available in blood money)
-No use of human sheild


Overall, the pros outweigh the cons. This review was as unbiased as I was trying to make it. It is a very enjoyable game to play. Again, for the hardcore Hitman fans, you shouldn't even be worrying about the review because you're probably already submerged into the game like myself. For anybody else, I recommend buy the starter pack first before buying the entire game. Get a feel for it. It takes patience and commitment and retrials. Hopefully you found this review helpful. May you all take on the role of Agent 47 and enter the World of Assassination. Thanks and have a nice day!

reviewText:
Most of the reviews I see that downvote this game seem to be from fanboys whining about how awesome a game from ten years ago was (Blood Money) and nothing compares to it. After praising the game for going back to the mechanics of Blood Money, offering huge levels to explore and tons of AI to deal with, and the replay value, they all slam this game and give it a thumb down. The main complaints, and I'll address them in line:

1) Always-on DRM. Put it in offline mode. It's the same game with the same content. You can do this from the menu, you don't need to disconnect your computer or sign out of Steam. You're welcome.

2) Performance issues. I've got an old AMD Athlon processor with a single GTX 970 graphics card that has yet to see any performance issues after 13 hours in the game. As most PC gamers know, there's a lot that could cause minor issues with ANY game. Chances are, the problems these people are seeing aren't caused by the game itself but rather their particular hardware setup.

3) Episodic release. While this *may* be a legit complaint in certain ways, get over it. If you don't like it, wait until the full game is released and then purchase. Don't bash a game just because you want to play it ASAP. They aren't charging you any extra cash over what they would normally charge for the game (unless you do decide to purchase it piece-by-piece).

And seriously...go back and play Blood Money again. It was great for 2006 but it doesn't hold up. The PC version doesn't have controller support, there's little AI to have to work around minus 2 levels (Mardi Gras and the Heaven/Hell party), and the levels are tiny save the Heaven/Hell party (that level was actually kinda massive at the time).

HITMAN is a fantastic installment to the franchise offering massive levels, tons of assassination options, hundreds of AI characters throughout, and the classic closed level"-style of gameplay that became synonymous with the franchise. If you're a HItman fan
date: this one is not to be missed."

reviewText: Back to Blood Money (Until this is fixed and fully released)\nIn the years leading up to this game I dreamed of an experience as wonderful as Blood Money, the formula was so perfect and expectations were high that the new Hitman game would deliver on what the fans wanted. Now while Absolution isn't the best as far as a Hitman title goes, at least it can be classified as a finished product. Hitman uhh......HITMAN is the newest entry in IO interactives most recognizable franchises, and it's broken. While I can't speak for all of the optimization, and performance problems of everyone allow me to share my experience. On booting up the game I put my settings to medium level of detail, high textures, medium shading and fxaa antilialising. As soon as the first training mission started, I get graphical glitches with the lighting. Shadows from light sources casting through walls, flickering constantly completely taking me out of the game. Other than that the game ran fine with my hardware which is an AMD 79503gb, 8gb ddr3 ram, and an intel i7 4770k proccessor. Upon turning the shadows on low the flickering stopped for the most part and i continued. Then onto the actual paid demo, I mean first entry in this episodic series. Everything was working in it's favor it felt great, looked great and reminded me of blood money times a 100. Then halfway through the mansion after running smoothly for 20 minutes it starts to stutter uncontrollabley, rendering the game unplayable. I was having such a good time too, the richness of the level and sheer number of ways I could accomplish my task is amazing. I love the disguise macanic and they've found a way to make it work in a sensible way. instead of being free to go wherever as certain disguises or needing instinct certain NPCs of that group youre dressed as may notice you, so a big strategy is finding the most unique disguise with the most access. All of the mechanics could have been so sweet, it's all there. I sincerely hope the developers address all performance issues and release the quality we Hitman fans have been hyped for.

reviewText:
The game crashed on the tutorial level for me and that was enough. I'm not going to screw around with this. Seems pretty hard to believe their QA team didn't notice a crash within the first 5 minutes of the tutorial.

The game has an online mode which of course doesn't work on launch day since it is overwhelmed. So then you have to play in offline mode, and your save games are not compatible with online mode.

You can map the numeric keypad keys but several of them simply do not work. As a left hander, this is critical for me as I usually use my mouse with my left hand and plant my right hand over the keypad.

I'm really disappointed in this release and I'm a die hard Hitman fan (Blood Money is so brilliant). I was really excited to play this game. I've requested a refund and will be waiting to see if they iron these issues out.

I strongly recommend PC gamers avoid this title until at the very least the crashing problems are addressed.

reviewText:
This is exactly what a Hitman game is supposed to be like, and I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. Great gameplay, huge levels and SO many ways to kill your targets, there's a ton of replayability here. And the game also runs very smoothly on my pc. With a GTX970, a I5 4690 @3.5GHz processor and 16GBs of RAM, I get over 60 fps at almost all times with nearly everything maxed out, except when I walk into crowds, but even then, the frame rate never drops below 40 fps.

Now here are the bad things.

Always online DRM: Why, just ♥♥♥♥ing why? The game is 100% single player, the only multiplayer aspect that it has are the leaderboards, so why is it that I have to be connected in order to have access to a playable version of this game? For some people, this might not be an issue, but I don't have access to relayable internet, so I'm ♥♥♥♥ed there. But even when my internet works flawlessly this type of DRM still sucks, because if I'm downloading something on the background or watching a video on a different device, the game just gets SO FREAKING SLOW. And even people with good, relayable internet will have trouble with this, as the game's servers aren't stable at all and will, sometimes, simply not work. I seriously don't understand why bother with DRM like this. The only good thing about it is the fact that people can't cheat on the leaderboards, but that's 500 light years away from being worth all the problems it causes.

Bugs: Half the point of this game are the challenges. Given the fact that you have very little original content, due to the episodic nature of this game, you are left with challenges to complete after completing the mission the first time. But these are VERY buggy, I'd say about a quarter of them won't unlock after you complete them, making you have to redo the whole damn thing and just hoping that this time it will be unlocked. This is completely random, as doing the same exact thing will sometimes grant you the challenge and other times it won't. There are other minor bugs in the game, but the real significant bugs are all challenge related.

Episodic Content: This game is episodic. The game will be released by updates of little original content at a time. In this release, for example, there's about 60-90 minutes of original content, half of which are tutorials. After that it's all replaying the same exact missions in different ways. The major problem with this is that it's going to ruin the story. I can't see how we can get engaged in the game's story, if we're only going to get 5 minutes of cutscenes every month. There's a tiny little bit of story in this first release, but I don't even think about it and completely forget it even exists, just because of how little of it there is.

Overall, I think it's an incredible Hitman game, and I personally love it. But they made so many stupid choices not while developing the game itself, but all the things around it, that I just cannot recommend it. It's too late to fix the whole episodic thing, but if they get rid of the damned always online DRM, then I'll give this game a thumbs up. But for now I say: Get it if you're a Hitman fan and you like the replayability aspects of the old games, who doesn't mind replaying the same level over and over, who knows the always online DRM isn't going to make the game completely unplayable for you at most times and who doesn't mind the episodic content. It's a long list, I know.

reviewText:
I have always been a fan of the Hitman franchise and this new one did NOT disappoint me.

I feel that the always online DRM is being bashed a bit too harshly. Yes, I did get kicked once but that was on the launch day itself. After that I have played it many times and have never got any problem.

I experienced no performance issues as well. It runs perfectly on my GTX970 with maxed out stuff at 1920x1080.

The graphics are excellent. The Showstopper mission is excellent and the open-world is really large and allows us to experiment and complete the objective in many ways. AI seems to be improved as well.

Although waiting for the future episodes is painful, the Paris mission itself is huge and offers many challenges to complete. Contracts mode is also a fun part.

Looking forward to the future!!!!

reviewText:
August 7, 2015
A new HITMAN?!  Hell yeah I'll preorder! (10/10)

September 30, 2015
Oh, so HITMAN will be an episodic game.  Not what I was expecting...but, f*ck it, it's HITMAN! (9/10)

February 19, 2016
Alright, the HITMAN beta is out!  A little buggy, and I would've expected the series to evolve at least a bit from its original formula (it doesn't), but it's a beta, and it's FAR better than Absolution. (8/10)

March 11, 2016
WTF?!  I paid $60 for this?!  This is exactly what everyone else got to experience in the beta, plus one more level.  And it can't connect to the server?!  Am I being punked?!  Agent 47 needs to track down the people responsible for this!  (4/10)

5:24am, March 12, 2016
I asked for a refund today.  (10/10)

7:18am, March 12, 2016
Refund denied :(  So basically I paid $60 for a game that I've played for 87 minutes.  Yeah, yeah, more content will be released later.  But I didn't pay for later, I paid for now (BEFORE IT WAS ANNOUNCED THAT THE GAME WOULD BE EPISODIC).  Yeah, sure, I can go and replay that ONE level for a month to figure out all the neat ways to complete the challenges, but if I can't connect online, WTF good does that do me?!  How about they take my money in f*cking episodes?!  F*ck this game, f*ck IO, f*ck Square Enix, and f*ck Valve!  (2/10)

7:12pm, March 12, 2016
So I finally got my refund.  Had to refund it to my steam wallet, rather than back to my bank.  Whatever.  I can now hold onto the money until this POS is done and deeply discounted, with enough to buy something better to fill my time.  Great exercise in how to get a refund. (98.6/10)

And with that, Valve and I are back on good terms.  No need to strong-arm 'em...unless they step outta line again...

reviewText:
Gameplay: While I do HATE the this episode release video game style, I cannot deny the fact that all the elements for a good hitman game are here. Finally you feel like you are one amongst the crowd again which is something that has been seriously lacking in the past few hitman releases. Levels do not feel as linear as they once did and you now express your own assasin style as you move in towards your targets. Also, things can go terribly wrong and you can still make it through the mission which is where I find myself laughing the most and having a great time. I can only hope this game ends as epic as bloody money did.

Story: So far the story seems very interesting. The story picks up sometime after agent 47 escaped the clone facility in Poland which was a mission you played in one of the earlier classic hitman games. I am interested in seeing the relationship between Diana and 47 develope further as well as enjoying the classic agent 47 personality

SHOULD YOU PURCHASE THIS GAME NOW? NOOOOOoooOOOOoo!  I wouldn't pick up this game currently, I can see there being a much better product, experience, and price ready for you in a years time once everything has come out and been discounted. I know I wish I did my research before blindy purchasing this game.

reviewText:
PROS:
+Big open worlds
+Full of tools and weapons and costumes to search for and collect since you don't know which will come in handy.
+Many ways to do but not complete a missions, the targets seem to have a just few reasonable ways.
+Replay value
+Good graphics

CONS:
-Big open areas often trying to track down only 1-3 ppl. You still get to deal with guards, staff and others in side missions.
-Good Graphics but much more demanding than Absolution if you don't have a good pc.
-Release only in parts so if you wanted to play alot you have to wait often. I don't mind since we don't have to wait another half a year for the release.

Its a couple points up from the indie game Alekhines Gun and a good game, it just can seem too big and empty (as far as targets) at times. Most of the time is dodging security or staff and collecting tools hoping you find the one or two that willl help you complete the mission stealthlly. AI can be a bit confusion, spotted or not even in uniform even if not facing them. The other issue is while you have many tools, often it seems limited in the ways you can kill the target due to others around. Either unhooking/dropping something on them or poison have been common. Also lots of waiting around, takes away some of the fun.

UPDATE: Second Level has been released and in the first hour that I have played it, it has been solid. Again, stealth fans should enjoy it and the freedom.

8.5/10 so far

reviewText:
As a longtime Hitman fan I'm feeling mixed about this game, so I will summerise it shortly;

cons
-no iconic sniper case
-no iconic binoculars
-scripted events only trigger when you act, the story does not progress on its own
-always online
-even when the game will be complete, it will be rather short compared to the past games
-game forces your grahpics, even my high end pc is only allowed low textures by the game

pros
-feels a lot more like blood money
-is washing the bad taste from Absolution out of my mouth
-47 looks like his old self again
-mission levels are indeed larger
-so many ways to deal with your target
-lots of interesting details, both story and enviroments
-smarter Ai (Absolution's Ai literally kept firing its gun even when not seeing you or looking at a wall)
-explosive rubber duck

I still can't give my final verdict untill the last chapter is released, but right now I can't say its a bad game, its quite decent (its not better then blood money, but it sure makes up for the horrible abomination Absolution)

I'm just hoping more levels will be added on up to at least 10 maps.

EDIT 1:
Second episode is quite entertaining, I'm liking the large size of the map, and its quite a nice sniper location.
Its a shame you need to do challenges to unlock weapons later on, but totally worth it.

First placing a proximity rubber duck bomb on the location where my target will go to puke after he eat his spaghetti filled with rat poison, and blowing him away while I'm already trying to get my second target to pick up the light flashing pale duck remote explosive, and blow her up when she does that, then erase security footage and exit the level,
Because explosive rubber ducks are fun!

First elusive target was quite something, and I barely made it.
But I feel bad for anyone with a bad internet connection as I'm sure you will lose your chance at this mission if you lose connection to the server midway the mission.

Aside from some minor problems I'm still quite happy with this game.

Gameplay itself is fine... what is not fine;

You literally had to make 1/5 of the game and you managed to ♥♥♥♥ this up? This is not acceptable, it's 2016 and games are getting worse and worse with each year, developers are being lazier and lazier.

Sums up why I give negative review, I'm tired of buying triple AAA titles that are expensive and are also ♥♥♥♥ing UNFINISHED.

I bought the Intro Pack (RUS - 4,99€ EUR) So I shouldn't really complain about price of the game, but I wasn't sure about this game, I've heard a lot of bad stuff about it but I also heard a lot of good stuff.

Honestly I'm ♥♥♥♥ing happy that I bought the Russian Intro pack for 4,99€ because this game in it current state doesn't deserve more money and I can only thank myself that I wasn't stupid enough to get baited into buying a DEMO for 14,99€.

On top of that Developers lied about game features, stuff that was supposed to be available in offline mode is not... they also lied about the time between release of new episodes, was supposed to be one Month... it's 7 Weeks, almost 2 months... nuff said.

My advice to people who still did not decide whether to get this game or not: Don't buy full game, don't buy the intro pack for 14,99€, go for the Russian version and pirate upcoming DLC's, unless they'll fix this game (I doubt that)

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=we1abilRUEo

Hitman is keeping truer to its roots than the previous installasion, Absolution.

This isnt a classic experience, like Blood Money was but it sure as hell is fun.

There is only one level released per month which to many consumers is a disappointment, to myself even, but this presents a reason fo rme to revisit this game with a refreshing appeal when I am inbetween genres of the backlogs in my current library. Once a month to spend a good week or two fleshing out all the remaining variables and possibilities in a new episode is a gimmick that works for me. I wont play this game out through and through before returning to another game like Arma or Rainbow Six Siege with friends and forgetting about this gem.

There is contoller support if that suits your fancy but keyboard and mouse gets the job done.

Theres been many a bug but overall as an experience it's been a pleasant one.

Would I recommend this to new players to teh hitman franchise, NO.
I would however recommend it to returning players who want to see IO Interactive compensate for their previous installation, Absolution.

For Hitman vets, one stage or all regardless, this is a must have game that emulates the classic hitman experience as best it can.

reviewText:
UPDATED 5/31/2016

Business model aside... This game is the Hitman game we deserve!! This game is going to be amazing when its released in full!!

PROS:
-Blood Money mechanics.
-Beautiful HUGE environments.  Marrakesh is the biggest Hitman level to date!!!
-Replayability! There are literally tons of ways to take out a contract.
-Hundreds of NPCs in a single level (think the Mardi Gras level in BM but all the NPCs are killable).
-Decent AI.

CONS:
-Movement animations are a little choppy and floatish".
-Keyboard controls take a little getting used to.  Example: I wanna use my scroll wheel on my mouse to cycle my inventory and not press "I" everytime.
-Targets are pretty easy to take out silently. However the fact that there are more ways to kill them than the previous games makes it slightly better.

SUMMARY:
I was on the "EFF SQUARE ENIX" bandwagon when I first heard about this "Episodic" release and I held off buying the game and considered not buying it at all. But being a Hitman fan I decided to read the Positive reviews from people just to see if the gameplay was any good.  From the sound of it

hoursPlayed: is tolerable (EPISODIC RELEASES OF FFVII IS A HORRIBLE IDEA!!!). If you like Blood Money and you can get over the weird release system Square Enix thought we wanted

reviewText:
I am really tired of reading negitive reviews, so I am adding my own positive review on the GAME, not the DRM, not the episodes...the GAME.

First things first, yes I am a hitman fan, have played the games since hitman 2: silent assassin. second let me address the issues everyone else is upset about.
-Constant Online: Yes, you do have to be online all the time, and yes they shouldn't of done this. There should be an offline mode, or at the very least it should not boot you in the middle of a level. If you have interrupts in your internet, then this game is not yet for you, hopefully they patch this. Nevetherless I refuse to believe that the ENTIRE game deserves a NEG review for this. After all, this has nothing to do with the actual game. I understand people are upset, but at least one review (mine) will not reflect this in my scores.
-Episodes: I am not a fan of episodes either, I've played a few episode games so far, and the waiting really does get boring. However, unlike other reviewers I'm willing to take HITMAN episodes with a grain of salt. Especially in light of what the game makers are working to achieve.
-For those who may not know:
-This is one of the first games to support Dx12
-The episodes / levels on this HITMAN are larger then ever before

Level Rant:
I'll admit, I didn't like the idea of only one level at the begining, but as I challenged myself to complete more tasks available in the game. I saw more and more details that the game developers added. Things I missed if I were elsewhere in the level, and what could easily be described as repeating events, in watching (while try to silently kill) my targets i saw little changes constantly in the main targets behavior. This is something new the game developers are trying and I applude them for their efforts. Also I would trigger different events at different times, and yet the targets responded predictibly (which is a nessacary evil if were going to set them up for a silent kill) without breaking their routine"...they would finish their current thing and then proceed to my trigger
date: so far i've yet to see a trigger fail...I did see a trigger not fire once
recommended: but I was far away from the target...it then triggered on the next run. Maybe this was a bug
hoursPlayed: maybe this was on purpose.\nOkay so I maybe rambling at this point
voteText: but my point is that the details the developers are adding considering the larger size of the levels is exteremly ambitious
helpfulPercent: and I support the month to month releases.\nI didn't like the fact that the April release was delayed until the near end of April
votesHelpful: but we do have the after launch patches to compensate for that. There is nothing saying that the May release will be early
votesTotal: ontime
votesFunny: or late. Honestly I've always been in favor of supporting the developers
commentsCount: especially if there is evidence of them working to improving the game. So even if May's level released in June
column16:
but it was obvious that the developers did it for a reason...I as a gamer who enjoys well developed games would appreciate it. Even if the waiting was killer.

Sum up:


Pros:
-Level design is done very well
-Details in levels are good

reviewText:
I am really tired of reading negitive reviews, so I am adding my own positive review on the GAME, not the DRM, not the episodes...the GAME.

First things first, yes I am a hitman fan, have played the games since hitman 2: silent assassin. second let me address the issues everyone else is upset about.
-Constant Online: Yes, you do have to be online all the time, and yes they shouldn't of done this. There should be an offline mode, or at the very least it should not boot you in the middle of a level. If you have interrupts in your internet, then this game is not yet for you, hopefully they patch this. Nevetherless I refuse to believe that the ENTIRE game deserves a NEG review for this. After all, this has nothing to do with the actual game. I understand people are upset, but at least one review (mine) will not reflect this in my scores.
-Episodes: I am not a fan of episodes either, I've played a few episode games so far, and the waiting really does get boring. However, unlike other reviewers I'm willing to take HITMAN episodes with a grain of salt. Especially in light of what the game makers are working to achieve.
-For those who may not know:
-This is one of the first games to support Dx12
-The episodes / levels on this HITMAN are larger then ever before

Level Rant:
I'll admit, I didn't like the idea of only one level at the begining, but as I challenged myself to complete more tasks available in the game. I saw more and more details that the game developers added. Things I missed if I were elsewhere in the level, and what could easily be described as repeating events, in watching (while try to silently kill) my targets i saw little changes constantly in the main targets behavior. This is something new the game developers are trying and I applude them for their efforts. Also I would trigger different events at different times, and yet the targets responded predictibly (which is a nessacary evil if were going to set them up for a silent kill) without breaking their routine"...they would finish their current thing and then proceed to my trigger
date: so far i've yet to see a trigger fail...I did see a trigger not fire once
recommended: but I was far away from the target...it then triggered on the next run. Maybe this was a bug
hoursPlayed: maybe this was on purpose.\nOkay so I maybe rambling at this point
voteText: but my point is that the details the developers are adding considering the larger size of the levels is exteremly ambitious
helpfulPercent: and I support the month to month releases.\nI didn't like the fact that the April release was delayed until the near end of April
votesHelpful: but we do have the after launch patches to compensate for that. There is nothing saying that the May release will be early
votesTotal: ontime
votesFunny: or late. Honestly I've always been in favor of supporting the developers
commentsCount: especially if there is evidence of them working to improving the game. So even if May's level released in June
column16:
but it was obvious that the developers did it for a reason...I as a gamer who enjoys well developed games would appreciate it. Even if the waiting was killer.

Sum up:


Pros:
-Level design is done very well
-Details in levels are good
-# of props

reviewText:
*I'll update this as more episodes follow*

After the release of Sapienza, and beating it undetected and using almost no guidance , I finally decided to write an honest review, having actually played the game unlike most people back in March. (Altho I get why, they should have updated their review, game does not suffer many issues now)

I'll be simple ; This is the best Hitman . Yes, im serious. Paris was amazing , but Sapienza just wow'ed me.

+ The best Hitman ever made thus far.
+ PLAYER FREEEEEDOOOOM! So many options, paths and gameplay styles.
+ Choose what to use and prepare before you get in the map
+ Offers many gameplay tweaks for the hardcore OR the noob.
+ Absolutely gorgeous enviorments and levels. The variety and detail is outstanding.
+ Very well made mix of Blood Money / SA stealth values with Absolution's controls and some gameplay aspects
+ Disguises are more balanced and logical this time around
+ Nerfed instinct mechanics
+ Close to community devs

-+ Episodic format . I'll leave that judge to you.
+- Some graphical and performance issues for certain users
-+ This game lives or dies on how much you like to explore and replay
+- Contracts mode could use some tweaks
-+ Elusive targets :( ?

- PS4 exclusive content
- Denuvo. Always online . I need to explain
- Some VERY bad framerate in some pc's . CPU heavy game.

I'd fully reccomend this to Hitman/stealth fans and people who want a more methodical, open type of gameplay.
voteText: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I like the game and the mechanics.  The game wants to hold your hand too much by default, but there are some settings that handle most of this.

So whats the problem?
The main issue I have is the publisher is not being honest about what this arrangement really is.   At the very least it's Early Access.  At worst, it is a creative way to rush an unfinished game out the door while mitigating a large portion of the backlash.

In short, the game is nowhere near finished.  We have a couple of maps to get a taste of the game and now we can wait or play the same map over and over..  but hey the season 2 trailer shows the real game we are waiting for.

What about the online features?
To me it's late content.  The timed offerings are there to get you buy the game.  Hopefully they add the limited content back in at a later stage and consider adding even more maps than planned.


Update:
I played the season 2 map and enjoyed it.  Very nice to see a decent size map in a modern game.

reviewText:
So, looking at the rest of the store page, there are a lot of bad reviews regarding the episodic content system and the wait between episodes, not to mention the lukewarm introduction in the form of the Paris Fashion Show, however, this review is based on content up to Sapienza.

TL;DR:
+ Graphically stunning
+ Hours of replayability
+ Living, breathing gamespace (Sapienza) with a real feeling of a busy town centre.
+ Vibrant storytelling without clumsy narrative.
+ Freedom to explore the game level with interpolated linearity. (Sapienza)
+ Encourages the player to re-approach the scenario with a different method or style.

- Episodic content is bad for those looking for a solid game to play.
- Disappointing introductory mission in terms of freedom/structure. (Paris)
- Benchmarks poorly on older systems. Recommend a GTX 950 + with sufficient memory.
- A few bugs here and there, which seem to occasionally get patched, mostly physics bugs.
- Have to play through the mission completing challenges in order to obtain certain features always afforded in earlier games (such as the TAC SMG (silenced)).

I've been playing the HITMAN series for 6 years, ever since my friend introduced me to Blood Money (I went back and played all the previous games too), and I get a lot of joy out of replaying missions, and exploring all the possibilities for the mission - without a doubt in my mind, this latest HITMAN game has proven to have the most intricate level of detail and possibilities to progress through the mission, and find entertainment in trying to repeat the process with different methods.

Paris was disappointing, in the same way that one would open the box for a toy, only to find it was smaller than you thought it would be, and that a lot of the parts don't move. With such detail put into the map, it felt like such a shame that you couldn't really take the time to explore it in peace and appreciate the gamespace the studio have created.

Sapienza has taken the game a few steps in the right direction - the way the game should have went from the start - 47 starts in the heart of the bustling town, reading a newspaper on a bench, looking across at the front gates to a large mansion complex. Unlike Paris, there is nothing to force you onwards into the objective - you can wander the streets, listen to the residents, learn the thoughts of the people in this small town. The story-telling in Sapienza is possibly the best self-contained plot in the entirety of the series and paints 47's mission in a different light - a relative hero, in the face of a horrific threat to humanity. A stroll down the winding streets can lead you to the marina, a high steepled church, cliffside cafes and more, and as you look around this well painted canvas, you begin to see opportunities - the vantage point from the church, the sewer access of the marina, the back passages of the cafes and beyond. There are many, many more secrets to see and opportunities to find, the challenges to complete, and of course, the obligatory gun rampage playthroughs. This will consume countless hours for me.

Then there is the matter of the maps still to come - if they have this same level of freedom to explore from the beginning and less linearity, then the only things that can really go wrong are the story-telling, and map design. I am looking forward to the next episode.

On the matter of episodes, as an MMO player, I think the episodic content for this game is fantastic. In a single session, if I play through a mission once, that is maybe an hour or so, plus the escalations, and custom contracts, which I'll play over a few days, and then probably revisit the game a few times during the month. In the rest of the time, I play other games, and will come back to HITMAN for a break every couple of days for an hour to break up the monotony of MMO grinding - this is great for me. For people who bought the game thinking they would get one straight 10-hour blitz, there was sure to be disappointment, but for those of you still looking to purchase the game, please check out some video reviews of Sapienza before making your decision, as the introduction package is merely that, and it does not show the potential of this game.

reviewText:
Best Hitman game of all Hitman game from its series.

This game's concept:
1) You get a mission to assasinate someone. You killed this person, unlocking new features for the same mission (like another starting location/ hidden weapon or gadgets in the map/ new items).

2) Then you play this same mission again. Trying to kill your target(s) in a different way/ style, getting new unlocks.

3) Repeat 2)

4) Repeat 2) again until you are satisfied and go on to the next mission (unless there's no next mission unlocked)

This sounds strange and boring, but it isn't! You always find new stuff and infos through your repeatitive play-throughs.
Some assasination methods are quite hard to find out and feels rewarding when you can manage to solve the puzzle".

Graphics/sound/atmoshere are nice.

9.3/10"

reviewText:
A souless, shameless repackaging of Absolution's engine with specks of Blood Moneyesque traits.

Nothing new is added to these games other than making it non-linear which it should've always been anyway so IO interactive shouldn't be congratulating themselves for that. All they worked on was map design and a new look for 47. Utterly pathetic to see how much of the animations they've reused from absolution as well. How about a more creative combat system rather than the same thing over and over and over again, i want to smack their head on a wall or grab an object and smack them mid-quicktime fight. This is 2016 and I have to say I find it ridiculous that this game falls so far below the standards of improvement that other games have been held to.

The game misses so many of the flourishes which made Blood Money a literal work of art. there are hardly any mysteries left to the player after doing the map about 4-6 times which happens to take about less than half an hour to achieve. Also logistics, WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ ISN'T THERE A GARROTE FROM BEHIND THE SEAT ANIMATION??? You literally showed the celloist i always used to do that to so YOU KNOW IT EXISTED BUT CHOSE TO IGNORE it. One of my favourite things to do was to set up the sniper when it was in the suitcase, imagine how cool that would look with this generation's graphics? But no, apparently IO interactive thinks the only thing we didn't like about absolution was the fact it was linear and that they could get away with minimal effort.

Now to answer a really obvious question. 'You recommend the game... yet your review is just plain negative' to which I say fair enough. It's not really clear but essentially I say this because the series is too good as a whole to abandon them now. It's not that this is necessarily a bad game on it's own, it's just A REALLY BAD ADDITION TO AN AMAZING SERIES and as such it should be held to a higher standard.

Bottom line is this game had and still has so much potential and as unlikely as they are to redesign it now at my behest I would still say support these guys so they meay have a better, more intelligent and dignified attempt next time round because yes Blood money was that good.

P.S I will come back to this review 'episodically' because ♥♥♥♥ you if they can do it then so can I.

reviewText: The game itself is not bad, but always-on DRM makes this a complete turn off.  Do not buy this game as it is, especially since its episodic.  The always-online requirement is dumb, its a singleplayer game, when playing if you get disconnected it kicks you back to the main menu and you can only load an older save - assuming you can reconnect that is.  My internet is fine, everything else connects fine but I could not reconnect to their servers.  Do not get this game!  They lied, they said only the BETA would require always on internet, and the full game wouldn't. reviewText:
This game definitely goes back to it's roots in terms of gameplay.  The mission area is no longer divided by load screens, as the last game was.  The levels are very extravagent and gives lots of options to complete a mission.   I have replayed missions a few times now and have done it a little different each time.

It's a little strange that they are dividing the game into downloadable episodes, but this probably allows us to play content faster than waiting for the whole game to be released at once, so I am ok with it, I am just eager to see the next mission!

Biggest CON for this game so far is the offline disconnect, if you are in a mission and you lose connection to the servers, the game exits back to the menu.  The autosave will protect you from losing too much progress, but you could still lose 5-6 minutes, as I did last night.

Overall, this Hitman game at it's core, is solid, I have always loved the hitman series, and am excited to see what they do with it as the episodes are released.

reviewText:
I kind of have to recommend this game. The gameplay is nothing short of brilliant. Yeah, it has some flaws here and there, but no game is litterally perfect. As a Hitman game, this is pretty damn close though. As much as I liked Absolution for what it was, this is what Hitman is supposed to be like. It takes everything good from Absolution and Blood Money and then combines them together. You're presented with a large map and the objectives. Then you go to work aby way you like. Shoot everything that moves? Sure, you can do that. Sneak in and steath-kill only the targets? Yes, you can do that too. What about killing only those in your way to get to the targets? of course, it's a Hitman game! You can even make it look like accidents.

There is, however, one problem. It's not with the gameplay, it's not with the graphics. It's the content. This game has one level, well, if you don't count the tutorial. It was supposed to be one map, then one months after another one would come up. The problem is that the game was released on March 11th, and teh next map, well it doesn't come out untill today, which is April 26th. That's way too long. A map every two weeks or so would be great. Well, not better than just having everything released on the date the game came out, but the age of complete games upon launch is sadly long gone. Anyone else miss that? And then getting an expansion alomost the size of the original game a few months later? Yeah, those were the days. No I'm not here to complain and bicker about how the gaming industry has become and yadda, yadda. But if you do get hung up on this sort of stuff, do not even think about buying this game, yet. When everything is out and the game is complete, which at this pace will be in a couple of years, the game will be fantastic.

So stick around for the full game, as this game is gonna be great when it's actuall done.

reviewText: This review is just after the release of Sapienza.  At first I was skeptical of this game, but went ahead and bought it anyway since I'm a big fan of the series (wasn't impressed with Absolution, but it was an okay game...it just wasn't a good Hitman game).  This, I have to say, is a Hitman game.  I love that they got back to the Sandbox style, and Sapienze is BIG with tons of options.  My first play through I went through it with reckless abandon, exploring and killing like a maniac.  My second playthrough I was able to obtain the sniper rifle and start in the safe house.  I then waited outside for one of my targets to appear and shot her dead right at the very beginning.  This is what I was hoping for, but it is still a bit sad that they decided to release it like it's being released, and there are still some bugs to work out.  One is the V-sync problem.  I get 60fps, but I see a slight tearing effect so obviously something is broken or I'm missing something.  Other people are reporting the same problem.  But, the bottom line is this:  if you are a fan of the Hitman series (the real one where you play on a map and figure out different ways of killing the target(s), and loved how replayable the games were in the past, then I recommend this game.   As of this review, I have 14 hours on an intro and two maps, and I still haven't explored everything on both maps.   They are definately making this worth the money, IMO.

reviewText:
I was hesitant to try the game because of all the negativity surrounding its release.

But the game itself (not the business model) might be the best Hitman game ever.

I went in with low expectations. The tutorial does a good job in conveying what Hitman is all about. The 'opportunities' (creative ways to kill targets) interface can be fully turned off, but is very nice feature for new players.

And then the Paris level completely blew me away. The scale is massive. It's probably 4x+ the size of your average level from 'Blood Money'. And it ran very well and still looked amazing even though I'm on an older system.

The amount of things to explore in this single level is insane. It's like levels inside of the level (levelception?). There's the 'infiltrate the auction as a guest' level, there's the sharpshooter assassin level and many more.
I've played through the Paris destination three times and I'm not even close to seeing everything and doing everything.

Admittedly you have to be more of a completionist and a tinkerer (a typical Hitman player) to get a lot of time out of it. The story is not really a thing and if you play your levels once and then you're done you're probably not gonna like it that much.

However, if you loved 'Blood Money' or if you're willing to view this experience as more of a puzzle game than a story driven adventure you're gonna have a blast.

reviewText:
Whether or not you like the 'episodic structure' or prefer to wait for the full game... it has no bearing on the QUALITY of this title.

While some users have reported the occasional bug, I have had 0 problems. The game runs flawlessly for me:

AMD R9 390X 8GB
Intel i7-4790k 4.0Ghz
16 GB DDR3 RAM
Windows 10

Now, with that out of the way, let's talk about the actual GAME.

My first impression while playing this game is that they took what everyone loved about the first 4 games (Codename 47, Silent Assassin, Contracts, & Blood Money) and took the few good ideas from Absolution (Controls, PART of the instinct system, contracts mode, etc) and have fused them together for a proper sequel.

Your options for killing people are far more extensive, you can use nifty things like tools (screwdriver, crowbar, etc) to play with things in the enviornment and set traps (Or just smash someones head in, whatever you like).

The worlds are far more full of people to prey on, and there are a lot more things going on. It feels like these worlds are more alive than in the previous games where people just did a round-a-bout route every several minutes.

Really it all comes down to this, if you enjoyed the previous Hitman games, you will enjoy this. Nothing is missing, and everything is improved. Don't listen to all the people causing problems because they hate waiting for new content. No matter how you slice it, the 60$ get's you a full game.

The only differance is you can get it AS content is ready and being updated.
OR you can wait till it's all on one disc.

Either way, the content you get is AAA.

reviewText:
Most of the negative reviews of this game appear to be down to both the always online DRM and the episodic format.

Which is a shame because aside from this the game itself is incredibly fun, and a welcome return to the sandbox style silent assassin fun of the old Hitman games, which used to make me cackle like a witch at a halloween party.

If anything I'd like a better map (like the ones in Blood Money) because the levels are so huge it's easy to get lost, but the new opportunities system is a very fun addition - with the odd little sly remark from Diana added in.

If you can ignore the annoyance of being booted from your carefully planned escalation playthrough when your internet does a burp, it's a very very fun game, and I'd still recommend it :)

Edit: Bit peeved by the elusive targets, given being booted can mean you end up failing the assignment when you haven't really had a fair opportunity (which happened to me).  Sort it out, IO!

reviewText:
This game is exactly what Absolution should have been. This is a true Blood Money sequel. It has a great graphics, amazing sandbox maps with huge variety of approaching your missions.

SHORT SUMMARY:


PROS:

- Great graphics

- Open sandbox envoirnment

- A decent amount of challenges to keep you playing, that is, if you aree that kind of person.

- A good amount of playing modes, including contracts which you can create and share with people. (Also in CONS)

- The maps are really huge compared to all previous games, which is kind of nice.

- Allows you to plan your starting game plan, as in what weapons you'll take and where you'll start. The option becomes more varried the more achievements (masteries) you unlock.

CONS:

- Always online play.  There is an offline mode, but it has separate save files and all achievements are disabled. Such games should not require a constant internet connection, because it is not an MMO and you do not have any interactions with other players.

- Episodic gameplay, usually with delay of releases. This means that you will be getting one mission per month till the end of the year. There is no info about additional missions after the year ends at this point.

- No difficulty settings. Well, no manual difficulty settings. You can not choose the difficulty of your opponents or remove certain elements from the game to make it harder, however the game itself is not that easy, if you are trying to complete every possible achievement and challenges.

- Voice over of actors is something lacking. Most NPCs speak native English no matter the location or country, and are voiced by same 4-6 actors. It breaks immersion for some people. Huge AAA titles should be able to hire more people for their games.

- Soundtrack is decent, but average. The game misses Jesper Kyd orchestral music which was a huge part of the franchise itself. This CON is more or less personal preference.

- Contracts mode is not as customizable as one would desire. You can mark up to 5 targets, select how they should be killed and what closes one should be wearing. However the options are flawed, and if you would like a person to be killed by a specific accident, the game will mark it as explosive or just melee kill.

- DX12 mode is still something to work on, due it giving ocasional glitches and crashes on certain types of PC Builds.

- Certian features were removed which existed in previous games, ex. Human Shield, Sniper briefcase. Developers say that they are working on those though, so they might be avaiable in later versions of the game.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CONCLUSION

My personal conclusion as a fan of the franchise is to get this game if you're a fan of the series and the gameplay it provides. It is trully a sequel to blood money and has a great atmosphere to it. Locations are beauitful and the maps are humangous for you to explore. One level feels pretty much like 2-3 levels of any previous game in the series which is amazing, and the game actually is more deep than it used to be. The so called opportunities feature allows you to listen to various conversations and make your choice on how to adapt to what you have heard, which gives you a feeling of playing in the moment.

Despite all the CONS of this game, I'd give it a rating of 8/10.

reviewText:
Ok, new mission is out, I have to update what I have written, but in fact, nothing much has changed:

new map was added, and if there is a disconnection from game servers, it is now possible to reconnect without loosing game progress. Also loading saved games now correctly loads information about chalenges and other stuff. But That is all for the good news.

The bad news is that the disconnections do still occure. Worse bad news is that the game gets unstalble after a while and craches simlpy as time passes. I have a save game whis is not finishable, because the game crashes aproximately 3 minutes after I load it, sooner if I kill someone. huh. WTF?

Anyaway, the new map is not realy good. I would say that it looks really great at first but actually it is much worse that the first map. Main thing which I do not like is that there are some predefined routes, but If you want something as easy and simple as open/break a window that is not opened from the beginning (even from inside), you are out of luck. How lucky we are we that at least doors can be opened as expected. Runing over the roof is only allowed on thre (I think) places. Not to mention climbing on anything (wall, hill, rock) - it is not possible, unless there is a sharp ledge to hang on. oh well, another WTF. It really gest booring by now.

Well, I think that this is more that enough update, for now. I will wait for another update/patch before even trying to play the game again, because I am now stuck with unfinishable savegame after some 4-5 hours and well, I have no intention wasting another single hour on any replay atemp unless I am pretty sure I will be able to at least finish the level...

So. I still do not recoment the game. Actualy if it was possible, I would recoment it much less than I recomended it earlier (and yes, I did NOT recomented it earlier).


Original post bellow (was valid before second level (sappienza) was released):
I will not say anything about the game itself as it is absolutely UNIMPORTANT compared to how unstable the game is.

My fist day (day of the release) experience was OK, but today (next day) it keep keeps crashing like 1x per hour and I got disconnected several times, which forced me reload, which does really made me angry (since I try to save as less as possible) and it looses all progress and sending me to the game menu.

And no, it was NOT problem on my side - my connection was perfecly fine and working all the time.

Also, I forget to mention, that the finished oportunities and chalenges are NOT displayed correcly when game is reloaded. Some do still couts as finished when the mission ends, but it is a bit hard to keep trak of all of these since there are so many of them a well, basicaly they are the only reason I stick with the game after finishing the level for the first time. Which means it realy DOES break my game experience.

So. I can not recommend this game. Instead I recomment to anybody STAY AWAY until they can make the game  (at least) does not crash when interet connection to their lousy servers fail.

If there would not be for those, I would be quite satisfied with the game (knowing it is not a finished game), but as things are right now, I really do regret that I have bought it in its present state.

reviewText:
Okay this is for fans of the game who are on the fence because of all these reviews.

DRM:

So for starters yeah the game has always online DRM but you know what, its 2016. If you dont have internet then you either live somewhere pretty terrible, or need to re-evaluate your life choices and get a job so you can pay for internet. The connection isnt even bad, I've had one disconnect and its cause the server actually went down for maintenance, and Im using my house wifi, tethered to my pc with a samsung galaxy s3, so i have no idea how bad these other peoples set ups must be.

GAMEPLAY/EPISODIC RELEASE:

Well lets see, the game has one level. And ive managed to waste 40 hrs on that one level. Yeah i wish there were more levels, but I bought the game knowing how they were releasing things. You'll read a ton of reviews complaining about the release schedule and honeslty I think its super immature, if you want the whole game, then just wait ffs, like you will be told when the last level comes out, same as everyone who already bought.

TLDR:

The game is an amzing nod to blood money, and its just ruined by people who have nothing else to do but grind thier lives away on steam complaining that the game isnt done" If you are a functioning member of society I'd imagine the one time you disconnect
recommended: you'll survive because you have real life to fall back on."

reviewText:
This game is good, really close to great. I don't review games often, but felt this game deserved one. I read a lot of the reviews and noticed that  game is getting bashed on for such silly reasons.

Here are what I've seen of complaints; which a lot are kind of BS or nit picky:

- Game is online only (Sorry that's a ton of games. It really isn't a big deal)
- You can't do xx when you could in past
- It's episodic (Ok? A lot of games are. If anything you spend $15 to try a game with plenty to do and see if it's worth it. I wish Fallout had done something like this so I could of saved money)
- Someone actually complained about the BONUS CONTENT of the elusive targets being limited on time... This person would never be pleased if they gave them the game for free...

Here is the basis. It's a silly, fun game that you can play for 30 minutes and put down without a problem then pick it up later. A great time killer, and really just buying the $15 will leave you happy, but I'm going in for the full set.


Runs perfectly on extreme settings
- Intel i5 6600k 3.5GHz
- 8GB RAM
- XFX Radeon R9 390X

reviewText:
I have to say this game has some great mechanics implemented within the game and the Paris stage (only stage available yet :/ ) is amazing but there is some flaws:

1.  Firstly the game as stated before only has one actual stage other than the Beta stages (prologue / tutorial missions) which can be completed around 40 mins if played quickly. There is a good amount of replay but not enough for a full episodical release at a price of £39.99 at all

2. The game will run at a smooth...ish 60+ fps if you meet the requirements but dips are clearly evident.

3. The game at its current state is lacking content even for a episodical release.

At its current state i cannot reccomend the game with the lack of content for the moment but will probably recommend it in around 4+ months when the game is released (fully) and has patches to fix the various glitches. Even as a hardcore Hitman fan i cannot say to pick this one up at its current state!

My good friend since High-Schoool has worked at IO" / Square Enix or whatever they call themselves for about  odd years. reviewText: I have never written a review so please excuse me if this is to short. I have been a fan of the hitman seires so when i heard of this one you could imagine how psyched i was when i heard of a next gen hitman game. When the game was released i went to purchase it but noticed it was being released in levels and that one level would be relased every month. Most peole would have been put off by this (Just look at the other reviews) but really i see this as opportunity to really expierience every bit of detail each level has to offer without feeling the need to keep pressing through the story. I purchased the 15$ version of hitman and was extreamly impressed with this game. I have put in 18 hours on only the first mission and i will continue to play through and explore the possibilites and challenges. The developers really did a good job with this one. I will most deffinetly purchase the rest of the game when i have the money but for now i will continue to complete challenges and public contracts because i can honestly say i cannot get sick of this games deep and rich gameplay. I highly recomend this game to any true hitman fan. If you love the hitman games and really enjoy playing these games over and over i feel you will love and respect what the developers have to offer with this one. Please do not be put off by the harsh reviews people have given this game. I personally have not had any issue with connectivity issues and have tested this game offline and it works just fine. If you truly love hitman then this game is for you. Good luck, 47.
