reviewText:
It's never gonna top Blood Money in terms of presentation, exposition, style, and artistic direction, but it's many many steps in the right direction.
A touch of the absurd, but no overly obnoxious characters. Nuance is the name of the game, i would have liked it more if hints and opportunities were restricted to easier difficulties (Pro, Expert, Hard, etc.) additionally, having unlimited ingame saves is certainly unbalanced. The ability to save during a mission was limited by difficulty in past games. This was a more subtle way of getting the player to devide the mission objectives into milestones, saving after acheiving a certain objective has been met, either set by the game explicitly, or a player set objectivethat after acheiving, allows the rest of their plans to unfold.

While miles ahead of HM:Absolution"
date: there is still an excess of hand holding as far as finding clever ways to dispatch your targets. Devs might say "intuitive"
recommended: but as a veteran of Blood Money it's a bit patronizing. However you want to look at it
hoursPlayed: the tradeoff is
voteText: in exchange for streamlined access to assassination opportunities

It's a damned shame. I commend IO for having created another solid Hitman game, a worthy sequel to Blood Money. They should be proud and I should be content and happy. Unfortunately the way IO and Square Enix has handled the situation surrounding the surprise always online nonsense which the game suffers, has been misleading and disrespectful to the point that I can not recommend this game.

This is what was communicated to us pre-release.
Originally posted by IO representative:Yes you can play the full game offline after you have downloaded an episode, the rep confirmed
date: "but there are live elements which you will need to access online.[www.videogamer.com]Just a straight up lie. You can not play the full game offline.\nOriginally posted by Hitman.com:Can I play HITMAN offline or do you have to be connected all the time?\nYou will be able to play the locations and missions offline. To play the live events
recommended: download updates or see things like leaderboards

They deliberately failed to mention those details before the game was released.

And then today

reviewText:
It's never gonna top Blood Money in terms of presentation, exposition, style, and artistic direction, but it's many many steps in the right direction.
A touch of the absurd, but no overly obnoxious characters. Nuance is the name of the game, i would have liked it more if hints and opportunities were restricted to easier difficulties (Pro, Expert, Hard, etc.) additionally, having unlimited ingame saves is certainly unbalanced. The ability to save during a mission was limited by difficulty in past games. This was a more subtle way of getting the player to devide the mission objectives into milestones, saving after acheiving a certain objective has been met, either set by the game explicitly, or a player set objectivethat after acheiving, allows the rest of their plans to unfold.

While miles ahead of HM:Absolution"
date: there is still an excess of hand holding as far as finding clever ways to dispatch your targets. Devs might say "intuitive"

reviewText:
Episodic release was such a terrible choice for the HITMAN franchise, the Paris mission was fun, and there are tons of ways to assassinate your target, and different disguises which allow you to perform special activities providing for tons of replayability of a single mission, and really makes User-Created contracts a good challenge and always unique.

Performance wise I was fine, definitly notice some FPS drops, other than that it went pretty smooth for me.

Was this mission worth the $15, sure. But if you can hold out till the full release. Do that.

Only reason I do not recommend it, is because I feel episodic games really kill the vibe and flow when trying to immerse you as the Hitman. After completing Paris full stealth and only using lethal methods on my target I was ready to jump into the next mission, but unfortunately I'll have to wait until next month.

EDIT: They really need to upgrade Contracts Mode. I just spent an hour finding hard to reach targets in Agent 47's suit in-doors, and kill each one with a sniper rifle. After losing connection to the server I get booted out to the main menu, and while creating a contract you cannot save. So I just re-did the entire contract and performed all my target kills in 47's suit, with a sniper rifle (my assumption was this would make it very difficult to complete my contract). Then I look at it when I'm done and wearing 47's suit is OPTIONAL, and it doesn't require the kills to use the sniper, it just says Fire-arm kill not what specific weapon. The whole point of attempting with the Sniper was it is hard to sneak your way in with a rifle on your back, but hey you can just use a pistol so why even bother.

What a great system.

reviewText:
Having played Hitman games for well over a decade I can say, hand on heart, that this new installment captures the mood, style and gameplay which made this series hit the big time in the first place.

Nowadays, so many people complain about being always online and about optimization and for some games these things can be a real issue. However, I have experienced zero issues with this game thus far.

The last installment, Absolution, missed the mark in my opinion and lost the feeling of the original games. Blood Money is widely thought of as the greatest Hitman game. I would agree with this. Well, for those who played Blood Money and loved it, I suggest you get this new Hitman. They have clearly listened to everyones concerns after releasing Absolution and this new Hitman recaptures the style and fun gameplay most of us loved in Blood Money.

Yes, it's episodic but the level that has been released so far is absolutely huge and has endless possibilites and plenty of opportunity to replay. For me, if people are just blitzing through the main mission to get to the next level, they are missing the whole point of a Hitman game. The satisfaction comes in refining your tactics and experimenting with new techniques.

I love it.

reviewText: This game is fantastic. The Paris level is a complex and convoluted sandbox with a trillion different things to try. Definitely the best Hitman since Silent Assassin. Don't pay 50 bucks for it though, get the 13 dollar base mission, or you'll cry about having paid full price for an episodic game, and that there's only 1 episode.\n\nGreat game, lots of options to go about the mission, and even the two smaller tutorials are missions in their own right, they just aren't as gargantuan and complex as the main mission.

reviewText:
First of all, turn off all the BS. Opportunities, Instinct, glow. Do it now. Are we good? Cool.

Yes, always on sucks.
Yes, I got logged out too when the server didn't respond. (happened twice in 6 hours)
Yes, it is episodic, and far from bug free.

But did I enjoy it? I FREAKING LOVE IT

The gameplay is just perfect. Strong lean towards Blood Money, but some nice parts from Absolution. Of course, the real star of Hitman are its maps, and while the 2 tutorial missions are... well, ok, the Paris mission is just beautiful. I found myself standing in awe at the attention to detail the developers put in quite some times. There are so many conversations to be heard. So many little nods that make the world seem real at the right moments. And the map design itself is just great. Hope they keep that up.

reviewText:
HITMAN Episode 1 Review:

As a big pain in the ♥♥♥ that I can be when it comes to picking up the little details that I dislike, those aside, I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE Showstopper. Seriously I was Very skeptic week before its release (maybe that way its better?) but to my surprise I turned out to be one of the best Hitman experiences I ever had. Simply put -I can't stop playing it.

Yes there are problems like:

Allways online DRM and poor optimization (which hopefully will be patched soon).
Lack of blood with some animations, some sound glitches - those are all can be fixed with upcoming updates aswel.

Take in mind that IOI is listening to us. Remember how we all wanted, now famous, Baby-face 47" to be gone? IOI completely changed his face model to look exactly like in CGI trailer and I dare to say that now its the best looking 47's face model we ever had.

Seriously
recommended: from gameplay and level design perspective - this is all that I could have ever wished from a Hitman game
hoursPlayed:
considering what Blood Money worshiper I am.

Showstopper is:

MASSIVE and by that I mean that pretty much every space / room it in has its purpose in the level - its not just an empty space for the sake of beeing "space".

Insanely detailed and rich with content. I mean I play it on PC with all settings maxed out to Ultra and boy oh boy it looks SHARP! Visually its stunning
voteText: I cant find better word for it to describe. It literally took me about 3-4 hrs on my first playtrough to figure out how to eliminate my targets. I was simply lost in the immense amount of on-going things/events around me. And I still am.\n\nThe world feels like it's trully alive. If you take your time and dont rush it
helpfulPercent: you can hear so many interesting stories and even Easter Eggs told by NPCs - and thank God those are not cheesy Absolution 'jokes'. Really love all the living feel of the level.\n\nIt offers Ridiculous replay value for a price tag of 13 Euros (in a good way ofc) - according to my Steam account I have already spent over 12 hrs in-game and I didn't even felt it. That's how good it is for me. I haven't even done more 40% of whats possible in this first Episode
votesHelpful: nor even started doing my 'perfectionist' speedruns yet. I don't want to rush myself just yet because I feel like it would be a mistake hah!\n\nSo far
votesTotal: with best things yet to come (Elusive targets and rewards) - I would rate this first episode with a VERY SOLID 8+/10. Once server problems will be taken care off and optimisation patches released - Im sure I could easily rate it 9/10 or even 10/10\n\nGreat ♥♥♥♥ing work IO-Interactive! Now excuse me

My recommendation will stay the same,it will only change if the upcoming optimisation update  fixes this issue.However,if you do own a AMD mid-high end GPU I would  recommend this game as I do enjoy it for its gunplay(eh is alrite),AI can seem to be clunky sometime but overall an 'OK'game.

reviewText: Following the disappointing break in style that was Absolution--a great game, certainly, but not a Hitman game--I was worried by the seeming limitations of this. With Sapienza, my worries were removed. For the first time since Blood Money, I feel like it's fun to explore, and attempt strange, sometimes even ludicrous means of killing my victims. It remains to be seen if the episodic idea will pay off, but Sapienza alone is worth the price of admission.
voteText: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have to say after being extremely disappointed in previous Hitman games, this one has really hit the mark on what made Blood Money amazing. Even with the episodic format being a big negative and the DRM (which I haven't had any issues with on a terrible internet connection), the game is a striking testament to what made the Hitman games great in terms of sandbox and planning. Just wish they had the newspaper article at the end of every mission. There's a very nice system I've been fond of, which is the custom contract mode. Basically what you've done in other games where you're a stealth archer making a backstory for a random NPC to kill, you can now do this and get rewarded in Hitman and share this with others. It's a nice touch and adds a whole other playstyle to the game.

The game started off a little buggy, causing system crashes when saving, etc but I found out my drivers were extremely out of date on my R9 280X 2GB, but after updating to the recent driver all visual & system bugs went away in both DX11 & DX12 and played 6 hours in one session without any crashes or noticable issues.

I'd like to note that the episode format is done in an interesting way which allows the dev team to put a bunch of time into each map release and appears to be priced decently. This is a very slippery slope but if done correctly without getting screwy with greed could produce high quality maps over time extending the lifetime and support of the game over years.

One more thing, that check point BS from Absolution is now gone and you can manually save at any time as well as timed saves.

reviewText:
I read the reviews before i baught it and  was leary of getting it. I've played the hitman series since the begining and was excited when they announced the launch. I can honestly say that this is the most versitile of all the hitman games, it gives you the opportunity to become your own assassin, giving you a wealth of opportunities, chalanges and weapons. the assecories that come hidden in the game waiting to be unlocked by levels of mastery are fantastic. i know most of the bad reviews on the game are for either the online server for the game or the fact that it hasn't  been released in its full content yet as they are still in the process of developing it. i can honestly say that it is worth the wait for the added missions with the size of the first two maps and their intricacy. as far as the online portion make sure you have a stable internet connection or that part will not function correctly not to mention the game has only been out for 2 months so let them get the bugs in the system fixed for the online portion. I havnt had any issues since 2 days after its release when the online server crashed

Pros:

detailed maps
intricate scenarios with lots of hidden opportunities
detailed contracts with good backround
good value for the contents

Cons:
requires stable connection to the internet
Online server is a bit buggy at times
requires patience for added content yet to be released

reviewText: Hitman is building to being among the best of the hitman series, truly. But modernization is not always a good thing. Each level is sprawling so far with multiple ways to approach and assassinate targets, something hitman fans have been asking for ever since the height of the series with bloodmoney, yet the magic that this gives the game is somewhat dulled by the fact that every way is spelled out for you in the form of challenges, poison target, electrocute target, prop accident...\n\nContracts and other additions however are more then welcomed and add a lot to the game and overall as each episode comes up it becomes easier and easier to whole heartedly recommend. Whether you love the thrill of the first time beating an assignment or like me love to perfecting the level, approaching it every way possible there is plenty of fun to be had.

reviewText:
I'm in love with the franchise since the beginning.
And I'm happy to say this game is my favorite. They (thank God) didn't make the Absolution storytelling mistake, the levels are bigger and a lot more open than ever. No linear puzzles, just the good old objective to kill someone. The maps are huge and open, with streets, open buildings, big areas, many people in it, many ways to find a way to target or to get what you need, hear or find things on the way to be prepared. Just watch Sapienza and Marrakesh.
This game offers a lot of hours to play without doing the same thing again. Like challenges, they're great. There's a lot of it, and that's mean you can complete the same mission over and over and it's still new in many ways. Like in previous games you just finish the levels on one of the limited Silent Assassin ways and that's really it. But this time the game has a replay value like never before. And one of my favorites that you don't have to be Silent Assassasin. With some challenges you kill others, sacrafice others but that's what our Hitman does for complete the contract. In the Final test we had to shoot the guy with an assault rifle? I didn't even use them ever in the series before and now I have the reason to do that.
The idea of the opportunities is awesome, listening to conversations just to reveal secrets or finding a letter with information, I love it. The unlockable starting locations, the unlockable starting disquises are so great, really good idea. The ICA can smuggle you in as a staff member? Hell yeah they can. This makes every restart a new experience for me. They can hide a choosen weapon or tool for you, too. They're the freaking ICA.
Blood Money never had the subdue, in Absolution you can't knock somebody out with a blunt weapon without killing them, and I just love throwing hammers to people's head.
My favorite gametype is the Escalation mode. It different from the main story, new targets and no save feature, and they don't make it easy for you. But you have to face challenges and even silent the the witnesses.
It's a great game, keep it up guys!

reviewText: This is the best Hitman game I've played yet.  I think the episodic structure for this game is fantastic.  My biggest gripe is that this game doesn't run as well as I feel it should.  I can run Witcher 3 at nearly max settings without much issue and with Hitman my settings have to be set to low in order for it run at playable frame rate. Every game is built differently I guess.  Still fun as hell to play. Love taking on missions from different angles. Looking forward to future episode releases.

reviewText:
A really solid stealth game. The maps are significantly larger than Absolution, and other previous games. Definitely makes the game entertaining to play many times, since you can take a different approach everytime. Some approaches can become very challenging, which is also nice.

My only complaint would be the graphics, which are average yet manage to put your computer under tremendous amounts of load. I can only get about 40 FPS on a high setting, even though I can run other more demanding games on higher settings at a constant 60. There are also occasional glitches (in lighting effects), but I haven't experienced anything game-breaking e.g. light going under walls.

Last but not least, I want to address the episodic" release of the game. Many people were complaining about it
date: although Square Enix announced this decision MONTHS before the game's initial release. Plus
recommended: it barely even affects gameplay and pleasure since the maps are so expansive. But I guess people will complain about anything.\n\nIn conclusion
hoursPlayed: this is a good game in need of patching and optimization."

reviewText:
The Hitman Experience
I'm going to try and elaborate on what this game is and what it delivers upon and I will not be short in my review.

In summary, the game is a beautiful stealth/infiltration game that manages to maintain the ballance between fun and frustrating. In it's current state (Episode 2 being the last release) it has two huge levels that are very well designed and offer numerous opportunities for replay in a multitude of new ways.

1. The Gameplay
The player mechanics have been greatly imrpoved and even though, at times, it might feel slugish, the game provides a very easy way to maneuver around and do what you want to do. On behalf of the game-world, it provides an insane amount of detail with opportunities at every step to change a route and try something new.
Because of its episodic nature (which I will talk of later), every map has numerous Challenges and various 'tricks' that you must complete to unlock all assets available to 47; these make sure the player is still engaged for the duration of the whole month, before the next episode releases.
And if that weren't enough a multitude of Contracts and side missions provided by both the community and the developers are available for you to really refine your skills in the art of killing NPCs.

2. The Story
As the missions progress, each episode reveals more of the story. In it's current state it is very ambiguous for me to really review it. I will come back to refine this review.

3. The Graphics
The game looks astonishing. The level of detail and the precision of that detail are both unbelievable. Now. granted, you will need quite the horsepower to run this, I am running it on a GTX 760 with a Quad i5 and it runs smoothly on High graphics. Hitman has never looked so good.

4. The Hitman Experience
Overall this game provides what it says it provides: a Hitman game. Granted it came out in this 'episodic nature' but I don't mind. It's not DLC, you can buy it all for full price. The fact that it comes out each month feels appropriate to me since it can keep you engaged for longer.
The game requires quite the skill and finesse and proves a challenge for experienced Hitman players. It is not really a gateway for new people to enter the franchise.

5. Updated Review
REDACTED: I have come back to this review after having Mastered both Paris and Sapienza and as of 3 minutes ago, also killing the second Elusive target. I can say whole heartedly that this game is worth your money and it is a full game that is merely provided in episodes (like a TV show). Some bugs are still existant and persist to annoy me by crashing my game, but given the manual save option it is not that aggravating.
I will be sure to come back again once more of the game is revealed.

In summary I will list some conclusive key features:
core Hitman game elements
huge maps, immersive environments
smartly designed NPCs
a vast amount of content
serial killer training experience
I definately recommend this game to any fan of the series (except Absolution -  if you only played that, this might be a completely different thing).

reviewText:
I'm a long time fan of the Hitman franchise. I played and finished all of the games except Absolution, which turned me off with its silly checkpointing and more linear feeling maps.

This new Hitman game is a huge return to form. It's great; possibly the best Hitman game yet. The levels are hugely complex clockwork masterpieces, like in the old games. A fully working save system is there if you want to use it, like in the old games.

There are wonderful new additions, too: UI touches that help you understand who can see through your disguises, community-made contracts that add tons of replayability, and optional hints that walk you through some of the really fantastic stuff you can do in these levels.

If you are a fan of the old Hitman games, just buy it. It's fantastic. Ingore the mixed steam reviews: those are from people who either don't appreciate this style of game, or have a silly philisophical grudge over DRM or video settings. Go read the reviews from episode 2.

reviewText:
23-May-2016 : Finished Episode 2 + extras
Equipment : MSI GT80-2QE Notebook

REVIEW (Updated) :
Episode 1 Paris is great, you get a big complex and detailed mansion as your sandbox to play with. But Episode 2 Sapienza is just amazing. You get a bigger mansion plus a small town! The map is bigger, more complex, more details, with lots of sniping vantage points... if IOI keep escalating the map size every time they release new episode, we could end up getting a one full city map by the time we reach Episode 6.

The game engine is still broken here and there. Every time IOI release new update to fix bugs, new bugs shows up. Not to mention IOI keep delaying the release of new episodes and elusive targets. I still stand on my previous statement that this game is an Early-Access Game" disguised as "Episodic Game".

reviewText:
HITMAN™ ReviewSixth instalment in the Hitman franchise with some major bugs as of now.

Was very excited to play this game and so it brings me disappointment to tell you that whilst what I've played of this game so far is great, it has been very difficult to actually play. First of all, the pre-load was a complete waste of time. I pre-loaded HITMAN™ the day before it was released and it downloaded the tutorial map and not the main map, Paris. So I had to download the game even after my pre-load. Bit stupid of Square Enix to do something like that.

The game has some major bugs. Upon my first attempt at trying to play the prologue mission, all I saw was bright glooming lights everywhere with no texture detail at all. I had to mess around with graphical settings and my computer settings for about half an hour to resolve this issue. There are random stutters during gameplay and graphical glitches, too. Not just that, sometimes it will say a body has been found even when you haven't killed, drugged or pacified anyone, just out of the blue.

The worst flaw is that this game is only available online, even worse is that I've disconnected twice, even though my internet is fine and my Steam is online. This completely breaks immersion. The same happened with Just Cause 3 and I just don't understand this online-only concept. It really makes no sense to me.

At its current state I have to say I can't recommend it, definitely not. I paid for the full experience, which was £39.99 for me. At the moment, there isn't much content and even worse there are far too many issues that need to be resolved.

When the game does work, it is fantastic. Even the tutorial maps were quite satisying. Paris is fantastic, though. Albeit the bugs and the online issue, this is all we hoped for, it is quite literally just an upgraded Hitman: Blood Money with better graphics, updated mechanics and hopefully some storyline too.

I will update my review as soon as the issues of HITMAN™ are fixed or at least partially fixed. At the moment, it's a no from me.

Pro's
+The game Looks amazing, the detail in 47's face is great as well as all of the NPC's.
+The graphics are top notch and i have been able to play the game at a solid 60 on high 1920x1080 easily, many reviews have been stating poor performance and i have yet to experience any of the sort (Any people that complain Must be unlucky or running it on a potato of a computer) For my specs look at my profile bio.
+I am a fan of going back to the start again showing the introduction of 47 in to the agency and how there relationship developed
+The tutorial and prologue are very well done and could even be counted as full missions.
+Paris is a good location allowing good access anywhere and makes Suit Only attempts much more ambitious as i scale buildings via drain pipes.
+Blood Money 2
+The episodic nature of the game also means that everyone gets to experience the game together as the 47 story gets put together.
+Disguises are much more thought out this time around and actually provide enough access with the difficulty of not getting caught by superiors or say for example you disguise as a body guard in the paris Level and Viktor Novikov is in the room he will see through your disguise because as any good employer knows he will know who are his bodyguards and who are not.

Negative's
-The game could do with more than one mission on the Paris level although Contracts and escaltion takes care of that issue
-Menu could be cleaner
-Had one incident where a person i was dragging got caught on a Henry Hoover and left me standing there in a Bodyguard outfit and a naked guy on the floor.
-Option to not take a weapon into the mission would also be apreciated.

Note: I have not experienced any Online issues so far and completely understand why they are there (I mean who dosent have internet these days and if you dont how did you even get the game) it stops cheaters from toping the leaderboards and makes sure that any updates are applied.

I will update this review as each episode comes out

reviewText:
I have bought the intro pack and do not regret it. I have been a fan of the hitman series since playing hitman2, but haven't played all titles in between. The game is still a little bit bugged and I somehow it does not let me select medium or high graphic settings, but I have only very seldomly encountered performance drops.
The first (non-introduction) level is very, very huge and the characters feel organic. The episode formate benefits the game, because it does make you really explore the levels and find all those little details hidden in the game and there are dozens of opportunities to kill your targets (I haven't found all in the first mission yet altough I played for 20h.)
For trying out new ways to kill your targets you will be rewarded with new weapons among other things. Unfortunately, besides the sniper rifle you receive quite early, non of the new weapons you receive are useful for the mission. What do I need 3 kinds of silenced pistols for? It's only really useful if you are planning to run amok... Also, although you are able to equip a poisoned syringe from the start, you can't use it to actually poison food/drinks... So how is that useful?
Still, very enjoyable game, especially when throwing heavy stuff on people :D
Recommend and looking forward to the second episode.
(Although, the full experience pack is quite expensive...)

reviewText: I'd love to say that it is on par with the fabled Blood Money, but as-is there's too much going on that puts off the experience. When looking purely at the core gameplay, nothing else, then IO nailed it in every aspect from level design to social stealth. If you really want to see what it's like, go ahead and pick it up, but if you're planning on committing, beware that the game is not polished in all aspects and patches have the tendency to break more than they fix. All in all, buy at your own risk.

reviewText:
I see a lot of people complaining about the fact there is only one level here. I was a little skeptical of the episodic release of the game so I started off but just purchasing the intro pack. I am now going to purchase the full game upgrade because I have enjoyed it so much.

I actually think the episode structure works for this game. It gives you some incentive to master the level. To play the game as intended and find every single option available. If I had the other levels right now I would probably just move on afer I had finished the first assassination.

The gameplay itself is really well done. The improvements made to stealth are great and give you a much clearer view of when you're in trouble. The amount of options is pretty immense and after first feeling overwhelmed you gradually learn the level with each playthrough giving you more insight into how to perfect your assassinations.

As of writing this review I have 16hrs on record and I feel I have alot more to discover. I haven't even touched contracts mode and some of the challenges seem impossible right now. I know though the more I play the more I will discover. In my opinion people complaining this is Just one level" really need to look at how much fun gameplay is in this one level and judge it by that and the fact there is five more levels like this on the way. There is easily going to be over 100hrs of gameplay overall.


I am now looking forward to the next episodes."

reviewText: I've been a fan of Hitman since the beginning and the games have grown into a well thought out and deep thinking experience. I thoroughly enjoyed this title albeit not a complete game, but I invested in it knowing it would be episodic.\nI've already purchased the full game because I enjoy the franchise and I want more. If this is the standard the future chapters provide, I've no doubt my money was well spent. A Hitman game is an experience not many games provide. The opening training area with its multi-tiered ways of assassination can compete with full priced games. There are many people complaining on the periodic system of releasing a new Hitman game, but as the locations are so huge, and there are infinite count of possibilities, you have a month to play locations (beside that developers feed you with new mission) before starting a next one. And the month is even not enough to walk through it fully.

reviewText:
English(ishish) version:

First of all, I'd like to adress two main concerns regarding HITMAN - always online feature and the fact that it's being release as an episodic game. Not one of these two thins are a real problem, as far as I can see. The whole problem around always online feature is absolutely unnecessary and pointless. Without any intention of spending my time on explaining why it doesn't matter, I have to admit that being always online is never going to be a dealbreaker for me. It's pointless since we're online anyways. The only drawback that I can see is that Squeenix and IO have decided to store our saves online, rather than doing so on our precious SSDs. In case of a disaster, disconnecting from the servers means that all unsaved process is lost. Bad, but not *that* bad.

Another thing, as I've mentioned previously, that many people see as troublesom is the fact that Squeenix and IO are releasing HITMAN as an episodic game. This isn't something new, just think of all TellTale games that have come out. Also, I'd like to remind you of all the DLCs that many modern shooter get (Battlefield and Call of Duty). This isn't something new and never before seen. It's something we've gotten used to and, frankly saying - HITMAN is just the right game for this sort of thing. With episodic content, HITMAN is able to deliver its content in its full glory. Instead of rushing through campaign (which has around 7 or eight maps) and complaining how short the game is - players will play it for months on end. We'll get to enjoy elusive contracts, contracts our friends and other players have made, special content and all sorts of things that devs can come up. Not to mention that maps themselves offer countless challenges and achievements. I can understand that some people might feel a bit underwhelmed and bored by replaying same map over and over again but... Hitman has always been about exactly that - find your target and utilize countless ways of disposing of them. Play, succeed and repeat.
As far as gameplay goes, HITMAN is rather good, even if it still isn't on-par with its predecessors (not Absolution! everything trumps Absolution). The biggest problem in the game is that it often feels rushed. There's no real opportunity to let player see things and plan his own way. Rather, we're forced to rush to certain events while AI mindlessly follows the same routine, over and over again. It can get irrititating sometimes, but given how gameplay options allow us to tweak the game - it can also be much more fun! I'd say that, when gameplay of any Hitman game is questioned, it is all up to the player and how they play. Some might argue that Hitman games are all about being slow, metodical and surgically precise (me me me!) while others might like to speed up things and just do it". I'd say that the latter shouldn't really even be bothering with Hitman.

All things said and done
date: Paris is a solid outing into the world of Hitman. It's really big. Much bigger than anything we've seen in Absolution. If my memory serves me right
recommended: I've seen bigger maps in Hitman II: Silent Assassin
hoursPlayed:
but I can't say that for sure. The important thing is that there's a lot of room for improvement that's needed. HITMAN must be polished and advanced if IO and Squeenix want to keep gamers interested for another six months.

reviewText:
Hitman is a solid game on a base level, however the developers had hidden features and content behind a playwall beyond most peoples attention or even capabilities that it severely hinders the enjoyment of the game.

What to use a sniper rifle in a level to assassinate someone? Good luck getting Mastery level 20 in Sapienza meaning you have to do a lot of things you might not want to, just to play as you want.

The game feels so restrictive in its structure I have to give it a negative review in this regard.

Pros:
Solid hitman game returning to its roots in a lot of ways

Cons:
Severely restrictive in structure and freedom of choice, prepare to spend tens of hours to get to play how you want.
Spotty performance on certain levels even on good hardware.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, there is a few technical bugs, which I can live with. All games have that, and they are usually overcome within the first patch. I managed to run the game in ultra resolution with no issues at all.

However, I cannot recommended this game for one reason and one reason only.

Two tutorials and ONE mission? Yes, ONE mission. Now, som say that it is my I own fault for not keeping up with the latest news regarding this game, as I just bought this game as all the prequels gave me hours of fun.

There has been alot of complaints about SE servers being crap, and you have to be online all the time, I personally have not had any issues. My only issue is with this idiotic business model, where you release a new chapter every 30 days. I cannot see how on earth I am suppose to spend 30 days playing ONE single mission.

In short: Do.Not.Buy.This.Game . . Unless its on Steam sale with 50% off

You´ll thank me later

reviewText:
It seems that nothing but the rating section is a circle jerk of offline outrage and kids getting pissy that they can't run the game in 4k on their toaster but the  actual game  has more to offer than that.


More importantly than that, the game itself can feel quite sparse, split amongst only 3 levels. What most people seem to be forgetting that this is indeed a hitman game. The mastery" system offers large amounts of replayability. Trying new things completes challenges that offers you new approaches to the mission
date: which you can select in the planning phase. I've put a stupid amount of hours trying to fully complete the game but i'm still only about half way there (Perhaps I just suck?).\n\nThe game however does have its kinks. People are right arguing that the game can often times run like utter ♥♥♥♥
recommended: and there are indeed connection problems
hoursPlayed:
(though I've only been dropped twice in nearly 20 hrs of play)* but most importantly I'm more peaved that certain graphics setting are locked based on your hardware. Square seems to have forgot what platform they are marketing to.

*EDIT: I've been getting alot more connection problems recently. At this point the game is unplayable. If this keeps up I might have to change my review.


Overall Thoughts

Pros Lots of content for only 3 levels
All levels have a lot replayability to them
It's not absolution

Cons The whole online mode should be cut
The game is buggy and needs optimization
Toaster advocates will dislike this review
It's not bloodmoney
In closing

reviewText:
Can't really recommend this to anyone other than hardcore fans, the games forces you to be online all the time, and kick you out if you lose connection, if you are offline you cant use the unlocks (snipers,explosives etc) or unlock challenges or any kind,  and lack of content is another reason for not recommending it right now.

However its a great return to classic Hitman of old, Big levels, lots of ways of assassination and generally fun gameplay, there are some issues like lack of/weak animations, the unlock system is very restrictive, lack of blood, certain scripts within levels hurt imaginative experimentation on targets, and no difficulties which makes the game was VERY easy for an old-school stealth player, even if you disable all outside help (map,instict,etc)

Right now i can only recommend to the hardcore old-school fans to get the intro pack and see for themselves what they think then make their own decision based on their experience with gaming on how they should act on the episodic and always online nature of the game.
Maybe with the future episodes it will get better and they will add a proper offline mode, then i will update this review" to a positive."

reviewText:
TLD:R the game is awesome.

If you are the typical ADHD child who was born after 1995 this game isnt for you.
The reason is that it takes patience and planning to make the best out of the game. It demands thinking and intelligence rather than mindless button bashing and shooting like crazy ( I.E The Division" fans).

Hardcore fans who grew with this series ( "Codename 47 " " Hitman contracts" and "Blood money") will love this game. it gives that same thrill of finding new ways to take out your target with finnese. You will get frustrated by this game if you expect to be succefull all the time. you will fail- a lot. but this is what i love about the game
date: it demands adaptation and skill rather than blind grind.\n\nive played 10 hours of one map
recommended: and i still feel like i want to come back to it. that makes me very excited for the future of this series. they made a good choice by going back and adressing the hardcore fanbase rather than going with the Absolution formula.\n\nIf you played blood money and liked it- you will like this. i had no problems playing on a 970 GTX and I5 proccessor."

reviewText: There are quite a few negative review and I totally understand that. This game is badly optimised and has a poor client-server design. The reason I'm giving a positive review is only because its game content. I've spent more than 60 hours since I purchased it (prologue + chapter 1 + chapter 2). And I enjoyed it very much except those bugs everybody else is reporting. I would expect it's going to take 150+ hours for the complete story so I think it's well worth the money. And thanks to the episodic release, I have the chance to fully replay all the possible ways of assassination.\n\nThe dev team is really slow in terms of improving the game experience and providing contents. They didn't patch bugs in time, although they've done a lot of bug fixing work since the game was released. And there are still quite a few of them out there especially the challenge unlocking system. They sort of got around the bug but it's just not fixed, which is the most annoying thing. The elusive target is delayed for two months and we don't know whether they are going to stick to the original plans of one episode per month.

reviewText:
I was nervous about this game after the first episode.  After the second, I'm beginnnig to think these episodes are going to be excellent. Despite people disagreeing over the episodic nature of the release, I think it's helpful. reviewText:
I don't typically write reviews - but this game is so right up my alley that I simply had to contribute to outweigh the negative reviews.

The new Hitman game is a work of art. I've played every single Hitman game, with Hitman: Blood Money being one of my absolute favorites of the genre. The level of sandboxing in that game was beyond anything previously seen. This, in turn, left me rather unhappy to see Hitman Absolution which was extremely linear and not at all a true Hitman game.

Hitman (2016?) continues the trend of Blood Money. There are tons of different ways around every single obstacle. It's beautifully sandboxy, and the mapping has so far been excellent.
People seem to complain about there only being two real maps released at this point (with only one of them being a non-training map). I find this curious, considering that I've spent close to 20 hours on that single map so far without getting tired of it. I completed Absolution in less.

I don't know how much people expect to get out of the €12.99 that you currently need to pay for the currently available material - but if you're anything like me, you'll know that 20 hours of gameplay (and counting) is way more than you should expect. I sprung for the full experience, and can't wait for new maps to become available. I'm having an absolute blast!

As for graphics/performance, I have not had any issues. The graphics (much in fact due to me not being able to run the game at High Texture settings) are still perfectly fine, and I have not had any issues with lag. Your mileage may vary of course - know that the game does require ample amounts of RAM to run well, and close to 6GB of VRAM to allow higher texture settings.

reviewText: about 90% of the negative reviews either complain about (1) the online-only mode and (2) the episodic nature of the game. neither of these are seriously valid complaints about the quality of the product being released. First, if you don't like the game in its episodic form, why not wait for all episodes to be released before buying. I find it remarkable that people hit the pay button, knowing full well that the levels will only be released in episodes, and then complain about getting into the very thing they knew they were getting into. The online-only system is a hindrance for those with connectivity issues, but that can hardly be an indictment against the game's conscious efforts to return to its roots, with some additional shebang (larger levels, variety of starting options etc.). In fact, almost none of the negative reviews give ANY credit to the developers for these, arguably, more critical facets of the game. if you're someone whos serious about the hitman series and its core characteristics, you wouldn't really pay heed to the rabble's rather mundane complaints. i've played hitman from the very first title, and this is by far shaping up to be the best yet.

reviewText:
DRM featureAlthough the game is notorious with its DRM feature, I've only been disconnected during gameplay three times during my 78 hours of playtime, and the game also pauses its gameplay for you to reconnect to the servers if you were disconnected. I have a stable internet connection and it was never a problem for me.

GameplayHITMAN focuses on replaying each episode/level. Besides the smaller two tutorial levels, Paris (Episode 1) and Sapienza (Episode 2) were both massive levels with more than 25 ways to assassinate two targets. The gameplay promotes exploration and puzzle-solving on the player's part. I call it puzzle-solving because you learn to put pieces together (i.e. after acquiring this particular disguise from this particular NPC or from this particular location, and then going to a particular location on the map with this particular item to assassinate your target). You have the choice to follow instructions from Opportunities" to complete your objectives or disable these instructions for a completely guide-less gameplay. The mini-map and the Instinct mode can also be disabled if you prefer a challenge.

As you complete challenges for each level

reviewText: With two episodes now, Hitman is becoming more of the game I wanted to see at launch. Quickly addressing the technical bugs of the game: I can't say I've ever run into any DRM issues so I can't comment on that , and yes, the game could use some better optimisation but at the end of the day playing on ultra graphics doesn't really imporve my gaming experience over playing on high or medium. Now the game itself has some VERY fun gameplay, each level so far has been humongous, with so many different ways to kill your target it almost feels like you are writting the narrative, not being guided through a set path (unless you choose to leave on the hints, which is your choice). As a result of this the game has some excellent replay value, and has given me hours of entertainment after only 2 episodes - it's not about just killing the target, it's about doing it in style, and discovering all the unique and cool avenues the game offers you. In part I feel this makes up for the episodic release format, and while I would have prefered for the developers to wait and release the game as a whole I feel it would be unfair to not recommend the top notch gameplay (despite only being partially released) available right now.

reviewText:
Ok, my first try at a longer review so please be gentle :)

First of all i'd like to clear some things about the game:

1. No it's not Online Only, but yes, the Offline stuff is basically just story/training. So we better hope servers keep up.
2. It's Episodic, wich means there is not much to play storywise right now.
3. It's basically a sandbox. If you like to murder people in every way possible, this is where to do it.

Ok, now that those are out of the way, lets see what it's all about.

The story seems interesting enough, altought it's pretty quickly played through the first steps, it did leave me wanting to know more. I play this with kb and mouse, but the game also seems to recognise controllers too, as it did notice mine right away. The game play was solid, nothing really new there either, but it worked out like it's supposed to do. I'm a bit bad at rating graphics, but for me it really looked nice. Some random npc:s in crowded spaces lack detail, but it's barely noticeable if you don't stare them too much, it's impolite anyways!

The bad (the stuff that most negative reviewers scream about) is the basically always online stuff. If you wanna have a rank from the main storyline missions, or if you wanna play contracts, or any other live stuff, you have to be online. If you are in the middle of a contract and the servers go down, it's mission over, start again after they get back online. I bet that will get people riled up every time a server goes down, it will force you to start over, or you can wait to get the connection back, waiting for servers is not something a pc gamers patience is capable of.
The second bad thing is the shortness of the first part of the game. It's not actually short for a episodic game, but it feels short for those who are not used to it. There's also an annoying DX12 bug (at least for me and few others) that seems to crash the first prologue mission if the dx12 is on, so i recommend using DX11 at least on the first mission, other than that the game seems to be working nicely for me at least.

The Good (that most reviewers seems to completely under rate!) is that this game really is more old school Hitman than the Absolution. You have to sneak, try to find opportunities and ways to move around without being noticed. It's done well. Some may disagree with the way game handles random events" as they are made so that they seem random
date: but in reality they trigger when player is near. There are real randomities too
recommended: but few of those key thing do wait for player to be around. I think it's a good way for this type of game
hoursPlayed: but i do realise it pisses some people off too. The game still has a good replayability value as you can do almost everything in so many different ways and after that you can just do your own contracts and see others fail miserably in them!\n\nI dont want to rate this game because it's just the first episode

reviewText:
So I've been an avid player of the Hitman series, dating back to the first one. I've devoured each and every Hitman game since then, played each of them a multitude of times and returned frequently over the course of years if only to return to a few handpicked favourite levels of mine. Like the the Hotel in Contracts or the casino in Blood Money and while we're on the topic; Blood Money's by far my favourite game of the series.

The level design, non-linear approach and responsive, intricate mechanics, having a base of operations, the newspaper reports that served as summaries of your past work, all of that made Blood Money an excellent game. A couple of years later, blending out the forgetable Absolution, which had more likeliness to a weaker iteration of the Splinter Cell franchise, I thought we'd finally get a worthy sucessor to Blood Money.

Alas, I was in for a surprise. The new game's again subpar to older Hitman games, in almost every aspect. I mean, thankfully I can't pull a sniperrifle out of my pocket anymore (Absolution anyone?), but other than that we've basically went one step forth and two steps back.

Naturally the graphics are better, however the animations are not. Aiming down the sights of your gun looks weird and it's even worse once you crouch and the professional holds the pistol like a ♥♥♥♥ing scrub. It just looks completely unappealing and I simply cannot comprehend how they ended up with worse animations than in Hitman's predecessors. Instead of holding larger rifles in his off-hand, they're now awkwardly slung over 47's shoulder on an invisible string.

Gunplay feels unintuitive and unrewarding, granted Hitman never had the greatest, but I remember spending a ♥♥♥♥ton of time just trying to get off the perfect series of shots when confronted with a target and its bodyguards and when in doubt, I finished one by one off after critically wounding them; another feature that's gone amiss. Also, remember how older games allowed you to shoot through doors? Yeah, that's gone too.

The new game's level design is pretty neat, to be fair, and paired with better core mechanics it'd most likely make for a great Hitman game. But not as it is, not when the game feels much weaker than its predecessors and more like a beta for a potentially promising Hitman game somewhere down the road.

To summarize;

+ level design is fantastic
+ graphics are much better
+ wide variety of options to complete mission objectives
+ proper disguise feature reinstated (to a certain extent. hell, you could put on a disguise and practically sprint through to your target and shoot it - nobody would blink an eye at you.)

- core animations are partially worse than in its predecessors
- former, much liked core mechanics missing (being able to wound, store a weapon in a suitcase etc)
- gunplay is absolutely boring
- killing melee animations are stale, unrewarding and furthermore very repetitive
- AI is literally braindead (kill a main target, e.g. the boss of an organisation, everyone's back to business as usual within 5 minutes)
- additional, former core assassin weapon arsenal has to be earned through a redudant online xp rewarding based component

All in all I'm very disappointed with the new game and uncertain how IO went from building onto their franchise, to stripping so many things away over the course of the last couple of installments.

reviewText:
The gameplay and graphics in this game is great. Its absolutely a worthy successor to Blood Money in that regard. It plays like Blood Money, except smoother and have great new additions, like the piano string dragging your kill along.

HOWEVER:

- The game is always online. This is mostly a mild annoyance and at least you can reconnect since a patch.
- Several annoying bugs. Guards have a tendency to die when you knock them out in a corridor. Guards often spot you when they're not even on the same floor. A guard even died during a cutscene, ruining my perfect score.
- ELUSIVE TARGETS. What the heck is this? Seems like a good idea at first, but for some reason there is a CERTAIN DATE to actually do the mission. I'd be fine if you only had one shot, thats ok, but a time limit where you have to do the mission? I missed the last elusive target because I had to work for the weekend in a place with no access to the game, so I had no way to do the mission during that time. This meant that I missed the elusive target. Now I see the next elusive target will reappear exactly the next weekend when I am again working. Meaning I will once again miss the target for no fault of my own. This feature alone makes it so I can never, ever recommend this game for anyone unless they somehow reveal that elusive targets will reappear at some point. But until then, stay clear of this mess of bad features. If you're a completionist, I'd say that this game is NOT for you AT ALL.
voteText: 17 of 31 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I really liked the idea of an open universe and custom contracts, so far I have submitted two of those.
I think playability and graphics are awesome and I'm looking forward to move beyond Paris.

However the PS4 exclusivity for the Sarajevo missions is something I cannot accept as a potential buyer, also the requirement to be online in a single-player game is extremely dissatisfying, I have lost already a few missions because the server temporarily disconnected. Not to mention that it's redundant when the piracy protection is already Denuvo.

Another great dissatisfaction is that I cannot set texture resolution beyond medium, I have maxed out all other settings and the game is running smoothly, to me resolution is more important than anti-aliasing and the like because the difference is much more noticeable when I'm in close range, I think it's fair that the player should be allowed to use the settings one wishes for his own machine, without limitations.

Despite all those reasons, because I see the potential of a great game nonetheless, I'm rating it positive temporarily until further developments, I hope your consumers can talk some sense into the developers so they can make the appropriate changes, that way everyone gets to enjoy the game they now own, and continue buying into your system.

P.S. What's up with the completely random crashes? I've had 3 of those in 17 hours but it's still a nuisance since some of the contract missions I was setting up, I don't get to save at all.

reviewText:
The new HITMAN lives up to the legacy of the original games specialy the Blood money and redeems the series from the lows of Hitman : Absolution by taking the series to new heights . There are so many ways to take on this single mission, part of the fun will be seeing other players’ creative ways that they assassinate the targets. If you’ve ever wanted to play the part of a super agent in a large sandbox, this is as good as it gets . Gameplay brings back memories of older Hitman titles, while new ideas such as the excellent Escalation mode keep things fresh.

PROS +

* Same hitman gameplay which we always want

* Great detail and amazing graphics

* Lot of freedom to play a mission in diffrent ways

* Episode 1 PARIS map is huge and lot of ways to explore

* Game mechanics are so cool

* NPC AI is really good

* we will get a  huge support from the DEVS
because of the season based content release


CONS -

* Online DRM is terible wont able to play it offline

* Need to improve loading times

* Game need more Optimization

* Constantly disconnects from SE servers

* Fps drops in some areas

* No story which we can say


I belive SE and IO interactive can fix these online and technical issues asap . So in comming months we can see this game evolve to a great HITMAN game . ( This is my impression for episode 1 , I will update my review on the coming episodes )

reviewText:
So much of the game relies on their external servers to function. Unlocks, challenges, saves, menu's (you don't even get a score rundown at the end of a mission when offline wtf!?). When the server goes down, you're left with a jockey barebones title. So yeah, basically, this game is always online... or at least it would be if they could even manage to keep their servers online, which they can't!

Then you got many issues which are not being fixed, content arriving late and some is completely missing. This feels like a beta/early access title, and it is, make no mistake.

I am a massive Hitman fan but I feel a fool for supporting this.

reviewText:
NOTE: MY OLD REVIEW IS BELOW, FOR POSTERITY.

I'm not going to bore you with an in-depth review as I'm sure there's plenty of them, so I'll cut to the chase: if you loved Blood Money, and liked/tolerated Absolution, this is the game to play. It's brilliant and the unlock/feat/assassination system is well-made.

I predict about 15 hours of content for the one level, not including elusive contracts/user-made contracts. Then there's more levels to come in the next few months.

HOWEVER. The server issues are an absolute nightmare. You are a slave to both their servers being online, as well as Steam's (yes, if Steam servers are down, then you can't play online on Hitman either). It takes (for me) about 60 seconds to go from menu item to menu item.

Provided you can get around this, the game is brilliant. Once they fix these issues, this game will be greater than even Blood Money.

Specs and performance:
Intel i7-4790K @ 4.4GHz
GTX 970 @ stock
Installed to SSD
Windows 7 (DX11)
Set to high settings everywhere except for shadows.

FPS: Anywhere between 45~ in NPC-dense areas to 120FPS in the bathroom.





OLD REVIEW:
> Always-online DRM
> Servers are down
> Can still play game
> No progression, unlocks, equipment, clothing, contracts, leaderboards, feats, opportunities while offline though.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's short but there's a lot of replayability in what's there. For 15 bucks is not too bad. The problem is it's packaged with DRM that boots you out of the singleplayer if you go offline and the game does not perform particularly well. The lighting is also glitched for me, causing it to flicker and scatter in weird ways. Noticeable and annoying, though the game is still playable.

Buy if/when it's patched.

Edit: Well, I need to revisit as I got sucked into the challenges. There are several ways to go about each mission and the challenges are sort of ticking off the boxes for taking different approaches. Paris is the only one that gives you rewards, such as extra drops, starting points, equipment, etc. to tackle the mission with. This gives you a reason to go back and take the mission on from different angles.

It really depends on the person if you're going to find that interesting. Once you get a path down you'll probably use it every time as it's optimal or provides you with a costume to quickly get around. This means by your 3rd playthrough you've probably seen a good amount of what there is to see and you'll be going through the motions for the rest of 'em. I've bagged 11 hours so far and while I had a lot of fun I can't lie that a lot of it was just repeating the same steps over and over. That doesn't mean there aren't other ways, but taking the path of least resistance can many times get you where you want to.

You can get good mileage for $15, and at least you'll see if you even want to give the rest of the game a go. I still think it'd be best to wait 'til all the missions drop since you can go at it in one go and waiting a month for the next locale is kind of a drag, but if you liked spending time figuring out things in the previous games I think you'll enjoy this.

reviewText:
I played this game more than 24h, and I still have side missions to complete!

Pros:
-Beautiful game
-Good voice acting
-Many Choices (where to go and how to kill)
-Smart uses for various objects (using a screwdriver to perforate a fuel barrel or dropping a propane tank into a fireplace)
-Very big maps, various interesting places to go.
-Interesting side-missions and good challenges
-Fun and various disguises
-A pretty good AI
-Even if the actions of the NPCs around the map are the same everytime you replay, you'll always have the feeling that each restart is unique.
-Probably missed a few more pros!

Cons:
-Episodic Game. Just... why?
-Ragdolls sometimes get stuck between thin objects like chairs
-Maybe the opportunities should be a little bit harder to understand how to complete them. This is almost like a tutorial right now.

reviewText:
The game is great. Mission can be completed awefully fast, but the challenges does keep you busy for a while. Regardless the game has a lot of bugs remaining. There are guards that can sometimes see you through walls and there are times when it shows you are compromised or hunted, when in fact you are not. Regardless of the flaws, it is an enjoyable game. I do not however like the fact that it takes more than a month for an episode to come out. The achievement/challenges are easy to figure outand I completed them all for Paris, just about in 3 days time. The content does not last a month unless you have minimum time to play this game. Also having to be online to play the game and to save the game is beyond belief. I don't know why anyone would design a game that way, but I would still recommend this game to all those who love the Hitman franchise.

TLDR;

Pros:

- Great gameplay and content
- Excellent environment
- Excellent graphics

Cons:

- Too many bugs
- Slow content release
- Online gameplay and no offline progression available
- Bugs, bugs, and more bugs

reviewText:
Really fun game, i'd give it overall 7/10. DRM issues are still there, but now you can play offline and it won't disconnect you from the server in the middle of the game.

The story is subtle but great, it's fun to have classic Hitman game . Graphics are ok, but physics are much better than previous games.

I only have 2 major problems with this game though :

1- It doesn't feel like a TRUE Hitman game. The game holds your hand throughout the entire story, IT EVEN TELLS YOU WERE TO GO TO PICK SOMETHING UP AND IT HAS  MARKERS!! If you don't understand what I mean, imagine a hitman where it would tell you on the map where the poison is, and it actually tells you to go get it, then once you get the poison it shows you where to go to put it in the target's glass,etc. Yes the game really does that, you need to turn off 7+ options to remove this hand holding, which is very annoying . There's no ''purist mode'' like in Absolution


2- Too expensive. There are gonna have 7 missions, meaning you'll be paying 70$ , but each Mission won't take you more than 1-2hrs. I think that's a lot of money for 12 hours of gameplay

reviewText:
What is going on with the gaming industry lately? Im am so disappointed. This kind of crap has happened on several game released lately.

As far as the game play, yes i enjoy it, its Hitman. If you are a Hitman fan then you will like it. Its along the lines of Blood Money, not that linear crap they pushed out last time. From what ive seen game play was solid except one issue i found. Open doors are invisible to the AI. Meaning I opened a door, entered  a room and stood behind the door. A guard walked into the hallway that i just came from. I could not see him, the door was between us. But he still saw me and shot me through the door. I never saw him but died anyways.

Other then that the rest of the game play was good. They added more complexity to the AI comments and behaviors. One example i liked was if you accidentally" walked into an off limits area. In past games you would be automatically considered hostile and the guards would start shooting at you. In this Hitman they act like real people

reviewText: I like Hitman Alot and ive played a fair amount of the older games in the past and was really lookin foward to this game coming out. The eposodic sales methord is intresting. Currently i dont have the funds to pay full price so to play a fair chunk of the game for a small fee is nice. However, im not sure that this will be a benefit in the long run. Comparing this game to somthing like the tell tale games the story is drasticlly missing and feels really disjointed making the satisfaction of finishing a mission not graet enough to make me what to find out what happens next.\nThe gamplay is really good though, simply put its a good hitman game. However there is a magor flaw currently and thats the DRM lock of this game. I started playing online played through a fair chunk of the paris mission made a couple saves and was thurally engoying myself. However, i was sudley signed out due to a server error... So i said fine online gamplay features wernt a consern of mine yet. So I tried to load a game in the offline mode and i had no accsess to any of my saves that i had previously done when i was online...... This is bad as i quite often play games on the go with the use of a gaming laptop when im traveling. This is a magor let down for me and in this case the reason i can not recomend this game right now. Hopefully in the futur this will be addressed. pure hitman fans might want to try the intro pack as it shows you what the game has to offer without a magor investment.

reviewText:
I came up with the 14.99 because I believe in this series.  Blood Money is probably one of the most fun games I have played (I still play it very frequently, coming up with different ways to play the missions).  Yes, Absolution took the wind out of my sails, but it happens.  Every series has a rough spot.

So I pay for the preorder, and the beta seems very familiar.  It's as close to blood money as I could imagine it being, and I got excited.   I played through the trainer levels (which worked superb) and was stoked for launch day.  Launch day comes, my game is preloaded, I press play, and...

Nothing.   I check file integrity.  Run as administrator.  Everything I know to do.  The game will only work if I set it to DirectX 12 (which my card does not support).  So, at this point, I'm on day two of owning this game, and I can't play it.  I've searched forums for answers to no avail.

I was alright with how they were spreading out the game.  A map a month.  Gives them time to focus on a particular map and make the game stronger.  If the map was already done, they could focus on the online aspect.  Make it stronger.  Make it better.  Unfortunately, now instead of getting to work on the next level, they need to fix what's already out.  What's already broken.

Ubisoft, Square Enix, and any other developer, mark my words.  If you continue to release broken ♥♥♥♥, you are going to ruin the community you have strived so hard to maintain the attention of.  Your core audience.  How difficult is it going to be to release games with no money because no one will buy the latest AAA release because they want to wait a few months because they know it's going to be worthless experience until that point?

reviewText:
Context:
I started playing the Hitman series very late. Blood Money was the 1st one I really got into and only played the 2nd one when I was very young.

Blood Money is one of my favorite games of all time. It got to the point where it became too easy, but none the less fun. Where I could complete all the stages in record times with a Silent Assassin rating without saving, even after not playing for months at a time. I ended up setting up challenges for myself like push or throw EVERYONE over a very particular ledge and such.

Absolution was fun, but never felt like a true hitman game. It focused all too much on story, the disguises didn't really work and the stages varied a lot in scale. Still played a bunch of it, and early on I did very well on the leaderboards.

HITMAN is like a jolt of nostalgia on crack. The stages are expansive, the objectives are fun and routes and methods are many. The episodic format does not bother me, but I know people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Each mission takes a long time to master and offer a lot of variety in their execution. They also have plenty of Challenges and Unlockables for each.

Something I wish they did implement is a remnant from Blood Money. I always enjoying having to purchase and upgrade my equipment. You could also carry a lot more items previously, though you have more drop points.

In short, I am enjoying HITMAN and would recommend it to anyone that liked Blood Money, or just stealth games in general.

reviewText:
Dispite all of the negativity regarding the episodic nature, i quite like it. The fact that IO Entertainment takes time to really polish the level desing and compliment the creativity of the player is a really good thing.

Pros:
- excellent level desing
- youre motivated to be creative with your kills, your opportunitys and your timing
- my medium spec pc had almost no game crashes or connection issues
- its back to the roots of being a sandbox puzzle game where your goal is to be creative with 'normal' items
I CAME IN LIKE A CANNONBALL
- great UI, but some controls are a bit odd, per example you cant change your weapon/item using mousewheel
- This game makes you think

Cons:
- too little level for the 50 bucks asked, but after playing sapienza, im really looking forward to the next levels and ideas
- At time of writing i've played 15 hours and im done with the main missions, and only got escalations (missions where the difficulty hardens) left.

Final thoughts:

SInce only 2 episodes fully released im judging upon those two. Paris is a good starting level, though a lot of liniarity, something i personally think of as Meh. Sapienza is a beautiful town to live, play and kill and has ranked as an instant classic among all Hitman levels. The 2 training missions are completely skippable but i dont recommend to do that.

ill give hitman a 6,8 out of 10. The lack of levels is the main part of this rating, though i am REALLY curious about whats to come. I personally like the episodic nature because of the love IO games is giving to Hitman

See this as an Early Access game, it makes the game so so so so so much better :)
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is the first Hitman I have played, and I am very impressived with the level of depth, the graphics and the replayability of the levels. Currently I have bought the Paris Intro version and have been re-playing it to unlock all the goodies. Very fun.

I haven't had any connection errors with the game - I'm running pretty average internet (TPG) on win 10 and it hasn't disconnected me once yet which is good.

My only recommendation for the game is giving us the power to choose how we upgrade our character. So as we gain mastery levels, we choose if we want a new weapon, a new starting location, etc as this will give a bit more satisfaction to the player. It's a bit frustrating now for the Paris level, as I am left trying to achieve all of the hardest achievements (killing someone with a speaker, etc) in order to get the final (and most juicy / enjoyable) starting locations and weapons.

Overall, 2 thumbs up (out of 3)

reviewText:
At the time of this review, there have been four levels released in total. Two intro levels along with Paris in the intro pack, and Sapienza.

Hitman took a quick nosedive after absolution. The game was panned by critics and fans alike, for not being a very good hitman game. It was story focused instead of the pseudo-sandbox like game like Blood Money, which had you try to kill targets in a level in a variety of ways.

This game, I'll just call it Hitman since it for some reason doesn't have a title (I hate when an established franchise does this, ♥♥♥♥ing stop it) is trying to return to its roots. The main reason most people give this game a miss is the business model, along with the always online. I'm not a fan of the online part, honestly. It doesn't bother me too much, servers seem stable and my internet is the same but I'd like the option to go offline. With denuvo, this game shouldn't worry that much about pirates.

The part where they release one level each month (Which you can buy separately, though you need to have bought all the previous levels to play the latest one AFAIK) is a source of controversy, but in my opinion if the levels keep the same high standard as Paris and Sapienza, it's justifiable. If you're not hooked, i'd suggest waiting for all levels to come out before making a decision about buying it or not.

Now, for the actual game. The performance, at least on Sapienza, is a bit lackluster. It doesn't look amazing but it does have a lot going on, the framerate hovers on about 50 for me (FYI, my setup is a 980, i7 4790k and 16gb DDR3 RAM) which is definitely playable but could be better. This is on very high settings.

The gameplay is reminiscent of Absolution, there's the same way to subdue, throw things at people and interact with objects, but it has been very much refined. The shooting is more satisfying, the objects give a nice Thud" when you hit people with them
recommended: although being in cover can at times be a bit finnicky. Luckily you don't spend that much time in cover

reviewText: I really don't like that individual episodes are priced much more expensively than buying into an unfinished game all at once, but what little I played was actually pretty good. Probably worth looking forward to.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
-Updated for Episode 2-

First, the bad news, the always online DRM is still there and they show no signs of even considering abandoning it. While it hasn't caused any problems to me, there's fair share of people who have had serious connection problems.
Not to mention the game still has pretty bad optimization and a share of bugs, while they have fixed some of the most glaring problems, they have managed to break other parts.

Based on the recent activity devs do work on the bugs and listen to feedback, which is how it should be and the game has really high potential. If they manage to fix all the problems and improve the Contracts mode to be much more precise tool of creating custom hits on the pre-existing maps, there will be a flood of extra quality content made by players themselves.

But lets move on to the just launched 2nd episode. Sapienza is hailed by a lot of people as the best or one of the best Hitman maps in the whole series and for a good reason. While it might not be the most difficult hit of all time, the  variance in the areas and massive amount of ways to kill the targets is amazing. There's tons of little details like NPC discussions and activity around. They also listened to community and made a good deal of Opportunities to have hard timer (while pretty generous, it still exists) so plenty of things will start to happen on their own, not requiring player to go around popping triggers to get the gears moving.

Overall the game still feels like it's bit of an early access and if you just like to breeze through things you might not get a lot out of it. But if you do like to replay sandboxy levels with different approaches, targets etc. you will have a good time.

If you are unsure about getting the game, give it more time, if the devs manage to fix and add stuff at the current rate the complete product will be a game that will challenge Blood Money as the best Hitman game.

But lets move on to the just launched 2nd episode. Sapienza is hailed by a lot of people as the best or one of the best Hitman maps in the whole series and for a good reason. While it might not be the most difficult hit of all time, the  variance in the areas and massive amount of ways to kill the targets is amazing. There's tons of little details like NPC discussions and activity around. They also listened to community and made a good deal of Opportunities to have hard timer (while pretty generous, it still exists) so plenty of things will start to happen on their own, not requiring player to go around popping triggers to get the gears moving.

Overall the game still feels like it's bit of an early access and if you just like to breeze through things you might not get a lot out of it. But if you do like to replay sandboxy levels with different approaches, targets etc. you will have a good time.

If you are unsure about getting the game, give it more time, if the devs manage to fix and add stuff at the current rate the complete product will be a game that will challenge Blood Money as the best Hitman game.
