reviewText: I like the game a lot. People are whining about the episodic launch and server issues but I've had no issues with either of these. I completed Hitman Absolution in 10 hours and never touched the game after that. I've already played 25 hours of this game and there have only been 2 episodes so far, so I should be playing this game for a total of 50-90 hours. I've had time to master the levels and get all of the achievements in this game (100%). I've been disconnected from the servers 2 times, both of which were in the game's first week. That is totally acceptable for a new game. I have had no real issues with the game. I'd definitely suggest you all to buy it if you like stealth games in general. Going in guns blazing is not the best option in this game, as you will die quite fast. So I wouldn't recommend this game to those who only want to play it like GTA and kill everyone with a shotgun/assault rifle.\n9/10 game for me.

reviewText: Hello everyone :D Throughout my years of playing many of the Hitman series, I have always become addicted by the vareity of strategies and playing fields in open world locations that Hitman known to offer me in the past. This one is especailly is a great imiprovement over previous generations of hitman games. Although HItman may not be perfect, the game developers did a great job in expanding the physical space of each mission, and giving us even more intereactions with our environment. Small improvements of course will be game graphic and fluid movement of our player character, but beyond that, the strategies and the locations are what makes Hitman really fun to play and replay as well.  For the first 2 locations in the game that i have played so far, as soon as i am placed into these missions esepcially for the first time, I become completely and happily lost from the immense freedom and chaos that I felt in these locations. The numerous interactions especially those intended to take down our taraget that we have in our environment are desgned with so much creativity andi imitation of life-like experience in the real world. For example, although there are only certain beverages that the targets will drink, so you can poison them, this hitman games has made it possible to poison almost every drink that we come across. We can pretty much flood any sink as a distraction as well. Although some interactions aren't necessarily useful. The options are always there to make the Hitman world very realistc to our everyday life. The reactions of NPC (Non-playable Characters) aren't perfect, but from my experience, I feel like I am being dropped into a real world as agent 47 and trying to blend in with the people around me as I commit a murder with a vareity of improvised weapon that are invisible to average people. With so much details and complexity in a reflelction of our everyday world, the game guides me through these opportunity that pops up with waypoints, which makes life a little easier in this huge open-world stealth game. This game just takes a lot of planning and patience to get through successfully, but it makes you engage mentally as I try to plan my assasination through and physically as my heart trembled and my eyes glanced quickly from one corner and person to the next one. The also cool thing about this game is that although it is not designed as a shooter game, you still have that option available with a variety of weapons at your disposal as you playthrough the game long enough. The only think that I could think of for improvements are just to improve interactions and environment just a little, but that's not a big deal for me because I say it is good enough already. Other than that, the Hitman team did a great job in their work !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!:D

reviewText:
I have never been much of a Hitman fan.  I am not a patient person and I don't like to sneak in games as I am easily frustrated with trying to understand when I am seen and when objectives have been failed because of some esoteric game play rule I wasn't aware of.  This game has some of those things but because it gives the player so much control over how to complete the objectives I oddly don't feel frustrated by it.  In fact I have enjoyed most of my time in game, discovering each scenario and how to navigate inside of the world.

My inital reaction to finding out it was episodic was confusion, but after having received the first installment I realize the brilliance of this plan.  By only releasing one per month or whatever I find myself exploring more of the map and retrying scenarios.  If these had been released all at once I would have played through it and honestly probably would not have looked back.

My only complaint is the always online component.  Although I have only had one instance of not being able to connect, it did make me realize that a long server outage would really suck if it coincided with my limited play time.

Overall I think this is worth buying.

reviewText:
Do note that this is a COMPLETIONIST game, just like Absolution was. If you aren't into 100% a game or if you just want to experience each level once or twice then you probably won't get your moneys worth right now.

At first I was very cynical toward the casualisation of this game. It introduced new concepts to the stealth genre that would only serve to further handhold. Specifically the 'Opportunities'.
Instead of being diligent and eavesdropping on NPCs to see if you can pick up on hints to devise a plan, the game will HIGHLIGHT the conversations and then give you precise directions on how to do your mission based on those, which is a total kick in the teeth. Now, you CAN turn this highlighting off, but in a score-based game its a total pisstake, don't you think?

That aside, there is a lot to do in a mission zone. Episode 2 gave us Italy and, oh my gosh, this is a HUGE and detailed (if a bit static) level. HUUUUGE. And its all used! You have no reason to go to specific parts of the map, but if you do they're all lived in! Theres a hippie with a sea-shell decorated room. Theres a street performer, theres a cafe, theres an icecream shop, a beach with sunbathers. Heck, theres even a road leading out of town where a car accident just took place.
THIS is where the game excels, you have to admit that there is a certain giddiness when a game you play has high attention to detail. In the mission, you will often hear NPCs talk about one of the targets deceased mother, who was old and frail. Lo and behold, if you look around the house, it LOOKS like it once catered to a disabled woman: The stairs has a chair lift, her bathroom had disabled facilities, her bed has a bell, and its all decorated to show her tastes.
Infact, if you look around town, you'll see that not only can you go into almost every apartment room, but you can even tell who lives there! They will never go to their rooms during their scripted cycles, but you can deduce where they live based on their personalities and how the room matches it!
For goodness sake, theres even the room that Agent 47 most likely lived in just before embarking on the mission!!
My point being is that IF they were to simply reuse this map, it would be completely fine! Without changing any assets, they could move around NPCs, change the context, and it would make totally justified.

The joy of the completion-ism of the game is that the game will demand that you assassinate the target in certain ways, and you have to discover how exactly to do that. I do believe that they could afford to be more cryptic, like we know that you can use a cannibis joint because the game tells you. How cool would it be if a player randomly stumbled upon the joint, made a post on the forums about it, and then someone else found a use for it?

I do take issue with the escalation missions. Escalations are when you do a shorter mission, and then you do it again four more times with extra rules. Its an incredibly lame way to increase play time because for about 95% of these they dont change how you play the mission in anyway. I play a mission for 10 minutes killing the target, then hiding the body. And then in the next level it says Okay
hoursPlayed: and hide the body". DUDE I JUST DID THAT!!\nWhat they should really do is give you the option to tackle the Level 5 mission from the get go
voteText: and if you do it then it auto-completes the previous four.\n"

reviewText: I like Blood Money, but this part is much better. While there is still some bugs left, we can at least be sure they will be fixed due to the episodic model. In addition to that, the content of the full game (season 1) seems to be reaching an enormous amount. Aside from the missions, there are a lot of challenges to complete in every level. Escalations bring actual changes to the level setup and give you new goals to achieve. Elusive targets are nice because they are real hardcore, only one attempt and only a limited time of availability. Something that I expect to get better in the future is the contract creation mode, where the community can create and share contracts. However, there is absolutely no way to filter these, no community rating system, nothing. Once we get this, this will be a great feature.\n\nVerdict: It is good and it will get better and better.

reviewText:
Really enjoying the game! The subdue bug is now fixed with the Marrakesh mission update, which was my main issue with the game initially.

This is Hitman back to open ended mission design that allows for many opportunities to be creative and several ways to approach your objectives. There are also loads of challenges to complete, escalation and community-made contracts, not to mention elusive targets that extend the already meaty gameplay even further. I have no performance issues running everything on max settings with a GTX 980. The game looks great, plays great and provides a substantial amount of content for the price.

Highly recommended at full price.

reviewText: Hitman is one of the rare games the episodic release format actually works well for, because each level (episode) is very much designed to be played through many times, rather than just once, before moving on to the next.  Certainly a player doesn't have to repeat a level and discover all different ways of killing targets, or complete more of the many challenges tied to each contract, but that great variety is where the real strength of Hitman lies.  If you enjoy the cerebral and planning aspects of stealth games, and the blind experimentation and discovery of puzzle games, Hitman (series) is possibly the best combination of those two genres, and Hitman (game) is the best that series has been yet.

reviewText:
I'm going to review this game as a newcomer to the series and hopefully address why I recommend it. Bear with me.

tl;dr I'd totally recommend it for newcomers (which is what I'm gearing most of this review for).

I'm a fan of Giant Bomb, and loved to see how much fun Brad and Dan had with this game on some of the UPF's as of late. I'm usually the type of person who jumps feet first into gaming and buys all DLC available. Not sure where I picked that up, but there you have it. So when I saw how much fun they were having, you can only imagine my surprise to see all the negative reviews. I took the time to read through them and there were a few common themes. I decided to pull the trigger (pun entirely intended), but went for the Intro Pack, since I can stand losing $14 on a game I won't play much. So, after my brief run with with, I have to say...it's pretty fun.

The first thing I noticed was how this game was broken up into episodes, and truth be told I approve. I like that I can just buy the intro package to get a feel for the game and, should I sink enough time into to warrant the purchase, buy the next episode, or even buy the rest at once. I understand why, on the surface, that looks bad. It's easy to say Well

reviewText:
I have one of the most healthy computers on the market, and I thought it would give me an edge on all the negative reviews. I LOVE HITMAN! Just not THIS hitman. However I know I could have, but I don't see that this game is in Beta, or any reason it isn't supposed to be complete.

Here's the problems:

-Not every one likes Tutorials, but I feel I need to experience every bit of the story I can. A Reboot to Hitman?! With Absolution features?! *Heavy Breathing.* Tried playing through the game 10 minutes in on six seperate occasions. Disconnected from THEIR server. Oh no worries, I'll just finish up and connect later to update my save game. Nope! I am Kicked out of the gameplay and returned to their Menu. Thought I was making a mistake, then I saw all the issues online. That made me mad, but I wasn't going to give up on you Hitman!

-I'm not really one to care about graphics, but this is 2016. I was surprised by the download of 7 some gb, but now I know why. I ran a benchmark, Hitman Absolution by far has the better graphics, and that game is older then this?! I would have waited for you Hitman, but 60 bucks for this? Come on! Come on guys! I have a Titan X, there's no reason for the game to look like a Xbox 360 game! So much clipping in it that totally broke the atmosphere of the game too. I don't think even Blood Money had so many issues with everything feeling so flat! Also I love Hitman for its design choices, this feels empty and flat as well. Everything feels so 2Dimensional. The execution buttons, The menus. Doesn't feel like a complete game. Especially a $60 game. Disapointing.

-There are some technical issues, the graphics aren't on point, but what about the game play. A lot of the game play is recycled from other games. Which takes away from a new feeling or a more viceral feeling. The item usage in the game is all I could tell in which they added. I couldn't even make it far enough to use guns though. :-( When I finally got a gun it crashed... Not much I can say on the game play, because I couldn't play it for 10 minutes at a time. For the hour that I tried to make it work though, it felt like the same old Hitman, probably not in a good way though... <.< Sorry Hitman...

-I will follow this game, and hope they finish it, or fix it, or whatever we're calling it these days. However I'm not putting any money down, until they get their shisa together.

reviewText:
Look, this is a decent recreation of the original hitman game. By that, I don't mean this is a remake, rather a new game that plays a lot like the original.

Therein lies the problem.

The controls - like the original are clunky as hell. If something should go wrong (and it will) there's no quick way to access your weaponry. For that matter, there's no quick way to access any of your gear or equipment either it seems.

Graphically, this can't be counted as a 2016 game. At best, it looks like a 2016 port. Playing on maxed graphics, the world looks fine within about 50m, nothing special, but not terrible. Beyond that, character models jerk and jank around while moving so badly you'd think they were a badly done stop-motion video.

The other big problem is the always-on DRM. It's a single player game that has always-online DRM. Enough said.

If you're a fan of the series, it's not a bad successor, but there's no way this game is worth the currently asked price. Let it drop to $30 at a MAXIMUM before getting it.

reviewText:
Currently COMPLETE POT LUCK if it works well on your machine. Many people having video issues, myself included. I have a i7 990x at 4.4ghz, 24gb ram, gtx780 and I cannot use over 1920x1200 resolution.   I would understand this if the graphics were significantly better then any other game but they dont appear so.  Also, if I want to get 12fps to see how much detail the game offers, allow me that choice.

The story and basic play features of this game ARE AWESOME...but they need to work out bugs and optimize before a solid investment can be made. Moral of the story, have the fastest computer, and the newest most powerful video card and it might work for you..... that is aside from the other bugs people are reporting.

Update: Seems to be working better with latest updates however all the above (minus bugs) still hold true.  Also, I finished the episode in an hour-ish. Sure there are other way to go in and play again but they should have included a 2nd episode with initial release to keep people feeling the game is fresh for a month until next episode.  Also, the AI is seriously lacking and is quite predictable...very robotic.  For a game like this the AI should have been a #1 focus then graphics. I've seen games in 2010 have better AI.

I really want to like this game but when youve done all that you can do within a few hours after spending $60 you get frustrated, even knowing its Episodic.  Again, I repeat for your ears Developers, should have released at least 2 full destinations (not including training) to keep people busy until 2nd release.  Perhaps going forward....or speed up the release schedule.

I wish there was a sideways thumb vote, Sad face.

K

reviewText:
I'm going ahead and making my first review EVER to ardently defend this game, so let that be established up-top in case somebody's looking for bias, because I might have it - I played and loved Blood Money to death, so naturally this game is directly up my alley and delivers what Absolution didn't. This review is going to take the format of a response to this game's criticisms, because my main motivation in writing this review is to illustrate my own confusion as to why this has mixed reviews.

My understanding is that people are super upset that this game is episodic and that, therefore, the first episode contains only one 'real' stage and two tutorial stages. I can understand how that would upset people who somehow thought that wasn't what they were getting...but if you're at all familiar with episodic series like Life is Strange or any of the Telltale Games, why are you upset about this? It was never presented as anything other than what it is.

Further, if game length is the concern, that basically tells us what kind of game you wanted to play. In this latest Hitman, if you are a one-and-done kind of killer, then this first episode will be done in about 2 hours - the approximate length of an episode of Life is Strange, but nobody was upset about that. Unlike Life is Strange, this game could have a great deal of replayability, should you be interested in experimentation.

The one 'real' stage is a masterpiece of level crafstmanship, with more details and methods of entry, attack and escape than were ever available in any stage of Blood Money. Fans of the series should be floored by the care that went into this one stage and the TONS of voice acting that went into bringing it to life. Instead, it seems like a lot of players just completed the level once and were done. Why? I have put in TWENTY-FIVE HOURS playing this stage, completing challenges. I haven't even really touched Contracts yet, but I plan to start making some.

The always-online DRM complaint I can understand far more than the length complaint, but that frustration just hasn't happened to affect me very much. Square Enix's servers died twice on me and booted me out, and I was and am STILL pretty salty about how saves can't be converted online to offline...but is that a dealbreaker? I don't see why it would be, unless your internet connection is prone to shorting out. I don't like it by any means, but I can deal with it, because this first episode has me very much impressed.

reviewText:
Used to be a big hitman fan, played through original to absolution, and now this...Disappointed.
Just talk about the downsides.

-Technical
- Poor Graphic.
Remember Absolution? That's better in graphics, and let's not forget Absolution used Glacier 2 Engine.
And this game? Just the Glacier engine.
- DX12 Support
I have a GTX 970 desktop, as well as a GTX970M laptop, both with the latest nVidia driver and it won't run in DX12 mode.
- Connection Issue
Connections are easily lost and you loose your game state.
- Texture Quality
Just look at the limousine's texture at the Pari's Level Entrance Scene.

-Game Issues
- Always Online
In offline mode, you can not
- gain scores & XP(mastery)
- beat in-game challenges
- choose different spawn locations other than the two offline ones
- AI
I can dress up in bodyguard and have the sniper rifle on my back without suspicion.
- Menu not so intuitive (even no Quit on the main menu)
- No Quit Promotions (accidentally hit alt+f4 and you're a goner)
- Play Style
No maniac shooting around mode like blood money did, you don't even have a health bar, once your cover is blown you die in a few shots.

and the BIGGEST of all
EPISODES?"
Meh.

But
recommended: the always online is the one must be fixed for this game to be playable."

reviewText:
An entertaining, brain-teasing, pretty, well made game. I'm not too familiar with the classic Hitman titles, so I cannot compare. I only completed Absolution, and I find this one a better experience, it feels like a puzzle with multiple solutions, and it's fun to try them all. I think it works very well with the episodic release model, because it would leave a player with a single level until a new one is released. Willingly or not, he'll have time to learn the environment and try different approaches. In Absolution I personally was too focused on the story progression, and didn't care for the mechanics of the assasination - and when you rush through a level, you might miss a lot of fun. In this game it's quite different, it feels quite natural to replay the same mission multiple times; you memorise the events and characters, and see them from a different angle each time. Challenges stimulate you to try different approaches, but I wish some of them were not explained, leaving discovery of their meaning to the player (like hidden Steam achievements).

I do not experience any performance issues, I have GTX 960 and an old Phenom II x6 CPU, the game is locked in Low textures, but looks great and gives me an average of 40-50 fps in its benchmark. I switched to Exclusive Fullscreen mode for a smoother experience, and do not notice any lag or stuttering. No bugs either yet, touch wood. Online mode works fine for me, I don't see a problem in being connected while playing. Offline mode worked in beta, I expect it work here as well. So technically I have no complains.

But of course, as usual, most things related to Russia are wrong, sometimes so ridiculous - it's cute. I mean, people calling each other comrade"

reviewText: Better than Absolution but not as good as Blood Money.  This entry in the series does seem to be more plot driven than previous entries so far, which I like (though only two episodes have been released at this point so it's still left to be seen how good that aspect turns out to be).  I was hoping that each episode was going to be more than a single mission per episode which has turned out not to be the case.  It looks like the developers are expecting community made content to make up for the lack of official content which is dissapointing.  It didn't take me long to complete the training and first two episodes which is also dissapointing.  I could go through and complete the levels in different ways and unlock other stuff but that gets boring quick for me and is a poor substitute for the lack of quality and quantity.  On a scale of 1-10 I would give it a 5.  My final opinion may change one way or the other once all the content has been released.  If you are a fan of the Hitman series than I recommend checking it out but wait for it to go on sale as I feel they didn't really earn their $59.99 on this one.

reviewText:
The latest Hitman has to be the first time that I've been genuinely impressed and excited when playing a modern videogame in an incredibly long time. The semi-open sandbox puzzles of previous hitman titles such as Contracts and Blood Money return with a mixture of certain gameplay elements from Absolution (sans the obnoxious disguise system or level design of Absolution). In fact, the changes to the disguise system in this iteration give it a nice balance between the useless disguises of Absolution and the lack of any challenge that occurred with the disguise system of Blood Money. And, this is further reinforced with the expansive level design of the currently available episodes.

I've gotten nearly 100 hours played in this game with most of that time being spent in Paris and Sapiezna. Both are  incredible levels boasting tons of various ways to go about eliminating your targets and the little touches such as conversations revealing the background story behind your targets and their motivations. Sapienza especially has tons of small conversations and small easter eggs that make the level a lot of fun to replay and explore.

The game isn't without its problems of course. The always online DRM and the finicky servers for the game can make it incredibly frustrating to play at times when you're kicked out mid-mission after setting up the perfect solution in a level. Fortunately, I haven't had this happen personally that often but the issue is certainly there and you should be wary of it if your internet isn't all that great. And, a lot of the patches end up adding in issues that were never their to begin with (such as the 'subdue kill' bug) which only results in more patches that continue the cycle.

Regardless, these issues haven't outright ruind the game for me as I end just having an absolute blast playing through the current levels and trying out different ideas and routes. If you've got a fairly competent computer, a somewhat solid interenet connection, and are a Hitman/stealth game fan that's in need of a modern Hitman title that has the potential to rival Blood Money or Contracts then I'd say grab the full experience or grab the intro pack and give it a shot.

I feel that this game is going to a good place I would not recomend buying it now if you are new to the franchise but for the long time fans who hated Absolution this is for you and for the rest of you pherhaps wait for the full release and a price drop if your unhappy with the release format.

reviewText:
Deciding to write a review because most folks have been crying about their technical issues and or complaints of DRM.

Technical side:
Game looks great, im running a not so powerful build i5 2300k and R9 270X at a constant 35~40 FPS with medium textures, bloom off, minimal shadows, no AA or AF.

There are some funny entertaining bugs when it comes to the AI that some folks might enjoy(i.e. charcters getting cemented to the ground, 47 high speed when loading up a save, I killed someone with a coin that was great...)

Gameplay:
Good
A.I. is a lot better than blood money and Absolution(i.e. Guards follow the targets, guards can frisk you, 1 staff member can see through your disguise)
A lot of challenges that make replaying the level worth it
Contracts is decent and works as it was suppose to since its inception in Absolutions
There is no hive mind NPCs meaning if you kill someone on the 3rd floor of the building nodbody will know that someone died above them on the 1st floor.
It's Blood Money on the Aboslution engine
It's $15....

Bad
THERE IS ONLY 1 LEVEL
Sometimes NPCs will spot you through doors,walls,giant trucks, etc.
Challenges seem to make the game a bit too easy at times since it gives you very specfic hints on how to proceed with the mission
If you get DC'd due SE's servers going down or your own connection then you might lose saves because that crap goes on their servers and not saved locally.

reviewText:
tldr; If you really want to play it, and you have a decent internet connection (as long as it's stable), buy the $15 intro pack.  Put it this way: if you don't like it, at least you didn't burn $60.

As far as the gameplay itself is concerned, it is very fun.  If you need an example, think of Hitman Blood Money, or the big open levels of Hitman Absolution (also the slow-mo shooting mechanic is gone, bummer).

Everyone says there's online-only DRM, but there's more to it.  The problem is you can't access the challenges, or customize the way you want to go about executing a mission unless you're online.  Want to start off working as a party attendant instead of a guest?  Go online.  Honestly, this is a terrible decision and I hope they get rid of it in the future.  But, as far as the server connections go, I haven't had any online problems since launch day.

reviewText: Unfortunately, I can't really recommend this game due to the draconian online vs offline mechanics. There are heavy restrictions placed on you should you choose to play offline (or if you're forced to play offline in the case of a server outage). This, combined with the lack of offline/online save syncing makes for a pretty miserable experience unless you can guarantee you'll always have a consistent, stable connection to the servers - which is not really feasible considering the servers may go down at any time, or for scheduled maintenance.\n\nIf they would allow online/offline saves to be synced with each other, I would change this to a recommend if you can tolerate the other offline restrictions". reviewText:
This game is fun, can't say i agree with the way the content is being released, but it's fun

Summary of who should buy Hitman
If you enjoy a large map where you can literally do anything you want to do, buy this game.

If you would get bored of the same level being played over and over, don't buy this game right now and wait until more maps release over the months.

Out of Ten
I'd give this game a 9/10 if every map was as enjoyable as the one that is out now but currently there is only one level and the thought of waiting an entire month just for another part of the story to be released brings it down to a 8/10.

Would recommend to hardcore Hitman fans such as myself.

reviewText:
This HITMAN game takes quite of a long shot. A too long shot. I hate to be the naysayer, but this game hits us rather than the ingame targets.

Generally, the game itself is solid. Various ways to eliminate your target, broad mission environments, exquisite level of detail, high quality cinematics, etc...

It has some graphical issues with the lighting going haywire at times, and those settings limitations are agitating. At least let me try at max and then lower the settings for better performance, but sadly, no way Jose. And there's also that annoying mandatory to be online at all times. I was in the middle of the Paris mission, and I got disconnected and literally the game kicked me out to the main menu to load again. And speaking of menus, they're very tiring and confusing.

But this potentially good game lacks the most fundamental aspect of all - and that is content. At first I thought that the episodic releases would be fine with me, but I was wrong. The folks at IO should have released the game when ready, meaning, including all other missions. This intro pack" is very unsatisfying. IN A NUTSHELL - NOT RECOMMENDED AS OF YET. WAIT FOR THE LAST EPISODE RELEASE

reviewText:
HITMAN™ as a game is quite refreshing in my eyes. It has improved upon its predecessor, Absolution, and in turn took elements from older games, namely Blood Money to please fans and give a greater gameplay experience.

In turn, you are able to explore your level, choose how you want to kill, how you want to look and how you want to approach your target, or targets. You can choose from a great variety of weapons inside a level, ranging from screwdrivers to lethal syringes, fire axes, various pistols and even rifles and shotguns in some cases.

The only level in the intro pack is the Showstopper level, which is disappointing, but already nice in its own right. The graphics in this game are stunning, of course, and despite people disliking 47's new appearance, I'm content with it as it doesn't necessarily matter.

Do you remember how he looked like in Hitman: Silent Assassin™? It was an abomination. An inflatable balloon, more like.

You can as always disguise yourself, and instead of an action bar to choose your weapons from, it returns to the weapon wheel in a Blood Money style fashion.

The episodic model is overall disappointing if not annoying, but I can safely say that under the circumstances of the company, it's understandable. IO Interactive had lost a lot of money and needed to make some in turn to avoid being closed down or laid off by Square Enix, and the game itself seems very promising as well.

However, not every game is perfect. HITMAN™ suffers from various performance problems, even on my machine, lowering my FPS to >30 in crowds, specifically in the Paris level. I hope IO makes an optimization patch in the near future.

The gameplay can be tedious as well, as sometimes the characters make one cycle onto an area that can be used to kill them, I.E. the showstage in Paris, only to never return or return in perhaps 10-20 minutes.

However, I think the game should still be played assuming you can do so. I suggest you have a good machine, as older machines probably lag like sin.

reviewText:
A fair amount of games are online only now days because we are  always connected  anyways. The always online even makes sense as they are releasing the levels episodically which love or hate really encourages replaying of the same levels.

Why replay the same levels? Because they are massive and there is a TON going on at the same time. There are options everywhere. Unlike absolution which was a constant straight forward path, there is simply a wide array of options in this one.

The online mode makes sense in the fact that you need to be online to gain unlocks which work with the online part of the game. You can still play the game offline if you wish but you will be missing out on a huge part of the game which is fun, contracts. Soon to be released are elusive contracts that come with rewards, there is a catch though, you cannot lose or abuse these contracts. If you lose then the contract is lost forever. You will be able to do these contracts based on the knowledge you have of the level, every floor and every possibiliy simply by replaying. The maps really allow you to explore to your hearts content, and do things your way and the best part is that they never get old.

I'm super excited for the future of Hitman and I cannot wait for Sapienza (which looks massive mind you) next month.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dt4eXBDKYwQ

If you have your doubts then just get the intro pack for 15 bucks, you get everything that is currently in the game at the moment and each episode will then be 10 bucks, it's a great pricing model albeit not very well marketed.

I truly believe this is the best Hitman so far. All it needs is some optimization and more content, which is coming every month.

It feels like they took Blood Money and increased both the size of the level and the amount of freedom in how you take out your targets. The contracts and escalation modes make replaying the levels really fun, as it sometimes makes you play in a way you might not have before.

reviewText:
As much as people are trashing this game in the reviews for things that I generally agree with I'd like to highlight some of the great things about this game.

The game is definitely a true successor to Blood Money and takes all the great gameplay and combines it with the improved mechanics of Absolution and greatly expands upon it. It's pretty much everything you could ever hope for in a Hitman franchise game, albeit the DRM and arguably the fact that it's episodic.

The Paris level is large, interesting, and provides thousands of ways to replay it. The challenges allow you to try to approach the mission in completely new ways and the sheer diversity of the level is enough to keep my interest throughout multiple playthroughs. The more you get to know the level the better you get at breaking it and finding interesting ways to complete it. In the game FTL you're pretty much replaying the same thing over and over yet it's the diversity of how you can play it that makes the game interesting. So why all the hate for Hitman?

As for the DRM it's really not as bad as everyone is making it out to be. I don't care for it but I've only been disconnected twice in 24 hours of gameplay and the game autosaves fairly frequently. The new model of gameplay encourages you to save the game at vital points anyway so what's the big deal?

As for it being episodic I really don't care. I'm a little bit disappointed but it does allow me to focus on playing one level at a time and getting the most out of it. When I get bored I'll just play something else. I am optomistic that it will give more time to the devs to make the game the best it can be. Many developers abandon games after they release them and it's nice to know that we get pretty much weekly content to keep us playing. I definitely can't fault people that feel differently.

reviewText:
HOW TO PLAY HITMAN

1 - Wait 24 hours after launch, server connectivity issues no longer a problem after 12 year old vloggers make their unboxing, tutorial, walkthrough, let's play, and review videos, then promply return to their medal of duty: hardlines playing and never pick up this game again

2 - Run the Benchmark, if your card can't run it smoothely at max settings, turn the settings to MEDIUM" <-- important step sometimes people forget how PC gaming works especially if you're coming from a console

3 - Launch the game.

4 - Before starting the tutorial
date: go to the gameplay settings and turn off all the in-game help and assists. You don't need them
recommended:
seriously. Figuring stuff out on your own is kind of the point of the game.

5 - Now play the first episode of the best hitman game ever made.

6 - Cross your fingers that future episodes will be at least as good.


There. It's not as hard as these other reviews make it seem.

Goodluck 47"

reviewText:
There are a lot of mixed opinions about the new Hitman, but what we get for the price is pretty decent.
I dont think episodic is the best way to continue the Hitman series but I have to admit forces players to go through levels in a much higher details and try much more approaches then normaly you would bother from earlier games.

GameplayPretty much  the good old 47s gameplay, wakky accidents, and skillfull takedowns. Looks like they took the best of blood money and Absolution. WIth two smaller training level and one huge level there are plenty of oportunities and approaches for your assassinations. Using disquises doesnt make you blend in with everyone and some some strategically placed NPCs make you take alternative approaches.
There a feature where the game shows you the best opporunities for the assassinations, but you have to do some exploring for them first and it can be disabled altogether in the menu if you think its to much handholding.

GraphicsLooks great with a lot of detail but AA is not the best. but really good lighting
Its an AMD game and runs much better on AMD. Even though DX12 can cause some small graphical glitches and crashes for me on a specific location, improves Framerate a lot and makes it run just smoother, I noticed less stutturing especially in heavily populated rooms.

StoryStarts with 47s recruitment and later jumps forward after the events of the earlier games.
Starts interesting but not much revealed about the story yet.
The more interesting story elements are around the NPC, a lot of NPCs have their own little story and personality, they help you a lot in finding oppotunities and guiding the player towards the target. Also they give a much deeper meaning and give a lot of context about the mission you are doing.
voteText: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have had no issues with playing it yet, although it isn't a massive leap ahead of the other hitman games yet, the levels have a lot of replayabaility. A lot more than previous games.
Missing difficulty system may make the game to easy for some, guides can make the game a bit too easy too.

There are too many different things to list so ill say this, the game is much much better than previous hitman games for gameplay. Everything is really smooth, quick, perfect, controls are great just everything.
and graphics are a step in the right direction but nothing thats eye catching (I play on absolute max in 4K on my 980ti).
It is worse for th episodic nature, lack of difficulty, and the month by month release.

Again, ill say it, ive had NO ISSUES WITH THE ONLINE, i can see why others might have but it doesnt take long to connect to the server and there is an offline mode regardless.

Final verdict is that it is worth it for now, and im sure it will only get better. Buy the intro pack if you want to test it out without commiting, its definitely worth the money.

EDIT: funnily enough, as of loading up the game after the review, i had a little bit of a hiccup getting online. I though i should note this, even if it only set me back a couple of seconds.

reviewText:
Heyyo, DEFINITELY one of the better Hitman games from this first episode at least heh. I love the way there is so much variety. I wanna try so hard to find all the awesome ways to do things. This definitely feels like IO-Interactive took all of the feedback of Hitman Absolution and focused on making this game as epic as possible and as open as possible... and YES! It is open. Paris mission alone has a lot of interesting ways to take out targets and try and get all the achievements to open up even more ways to start the mission or have different tools to take with me on the missions.

Of course, one of the big flashy things for PC is DirectX 12 and on AMD GPU? It definitely helps. It's like a free overclock on top of my overclock hah. On the benchmark? I get 7fps average boost versus Dx11 on top of my 1920x1080 on Ultra (no super sampling though) so I went from 75fps to 81fps so I'm super happy. :)

My full specs are...
Windows 10 Pro 64-bit
Intel Core i7 3770K @ 4.40GHz Ivy Bridge 22nm Technology
CORSAIR Hydro Series H80 (CWCH80) High Performance Liquid CPU Cooler
16.0GB (4x4GB) Kingston Dual-Channel DDR3 @ 2133MHz (11-12-11-30 @ 1.65V)
Gigabyte Technology Co., Ltd. Z68X-UD7-B3 (Socket 1155 BIOS F11a)
ASUS VE278 27 LCD (1920x1080@60Hz via DisplayPort with RGB full)
MSI R9 390 Gaming 8G (OC 1120MHz core
date:
1525MHz mem & +10% power)
Creative Labs Sound Blaster Recon3D Fatal1ty Professional PCI-E
Visiontek's Bigfoot Network Killer 2100 PCI-E Network Interface Card

So after performance I might as well talk about graphics and as you can see from the screenshots? It looks fantastic. The environments are very nicely done! So many voices and conversations
recommended: the music is spot-on and very nicely done! The Paris and first training missions beats are stuck in my head haha. I just love how everything has tied together so well on this. :)\n\nAlright... so meow for my opinion on the episodic. Mine is fantastic. I do Love it... why? How many game releases have been flakey in the last two years or so? So many big titles falling flat on their faces on release!!! Unlike Watch_Dogs where $60 just evaporated out of my wallet? With episodic
hoursPlayed: IO-Interactive is essentially risking people not getting the rest of the episodes if their first episode flops or if they feel it's not the game they wanted... but luckily for them? It's not a flop. It works great.\n\nThe Square Enix always online DRM is a bit of a bummer since they don't let you cross-play offline and online save games... there should just be a warning like "hey if you continue this will be converted to an offline play session & save" or at least let it log it and still carry to the online mode... but maybe that progression system is their form of copy protection to revent people who pirate the game from getting all of the goodies? Just my guess. Tbh I'll be buying the upgrade pack since this went so well so far. :)"

reviewText:
New Hitman game shows great promise
I haven't played many Hitman titles over the years so I'll be judging this one primarily on it's own merit. First off, it runs smoothly with the occasional freeze. Once or twice that nearly cost me a mission but usually it was fine. The game looks great. And it feels immersive and really like an assassin game should feel. Plenty of ways to kill your targets and the world in which they operate works without your presence. They keep doing their thing even if you aren't there to eavesdrop or interrupt their schemes. I get a steady framerate (gtx 970) and use high settings. Sometimes when the load is especially heavy the game freezes up and then continues like nothing happened. Never crashing or anything weird like that. It's far from perfect but ok.

I purchased the intro pack. And after trying it out I know I will buy the rest of the game. But this allowed me to try it out and feel around it. I don't know when I'll buy considering the current selection of missions is few. Though the game challenges you to repeat the same missions over and over again in different ways which actually works. It's fun to experiment in this game. And rarely does the game punish unjustly for your attempts at freeform assassination. You can't go in guns blazin but that isn't unfair or wrong. This is the wrong game if that is what you want from your gaming experience.

The bad stuff

Always online DRM is really annoying for people with unstable connection or living in more rural parts. I have a great connection and wasn't annoyed. Which mean that during my brief time with the game (will update if needed) their servers worked well. But I understand that people have a problem with this. It's just not justifiable for a single player game with some minor online features.

Triple A games cost a lot. And this game is obviously no exception. So it might annoy people to sell a not finished product at full price. I agree. That's why if you want to try it you should buy the intro pack first. I don't recommend anyone who just want to see if this is any good to buy the full game. But I felt I really got something out of the 13 euros I spent on the intro pack. It was fun. It felt modern and good.

Considering that the full price is for unreleased content I can't recommend it yet. But I will recommend the intro pack which is what I bought.

reviewText: Agent 47 Is Back
voteText: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There are a lot of mixed opinions about the new Hitman, but what we get for the price is pretty decent.
I dont think episodic is the best way to continue the Hitman series but I have to admit forces players to go through levels in a much higher details and try much more approaches then normaly you would bother from earlier games.

GameplayPretty much  the good old 47s gameplay, wakky accidents, and skillfull takedowns. Looks like they took the best of blood money and Absolution. WIth two smaller training level and one huge level there are plenty of oportunities and approaches for your assassinations. Using disquises doesnt make you blend in with everyone and some some strategically placed NPCs make you take alternative approaches.
There a feature where the game shows you the best opporunities for the assassinations, but you have to do some exploring for them first and it can be disabled altogether in the menu if you think its to much handholding.

GraphicsLooks great with a lot of detail but AA is not the best. but really good lighting
Its an AMD game and runs much better on AMD. Even though DX12 can cause some small graphical glitches and crashes for me on a specific location, improves Framerate a lot and makes it run just smoother, I noticed less stutturing especially in heavily populated rooms.

StoryStarts with 47s recruitment and later jumps forward after the events of the earlier games.
Starts interesting but not much revealed about the story yet.
The more interesting story elements are around the NPC, a lot of NPCs have their own little story and personality, they help you a lot in finding oppotunities and guiding the player towards the target. Also they give a much deeper meaning and give a lot of context about the mission you are doing.

reviewText:
I have had no issues with playing it yet, although it isn't a massive leap ahead of the other hitman games yet, the levels have a lot of replayabaility. A lot more than previous games.
Missing difficulty system may make the game to easy for some, guides can make the game a bit too easy too.

There are too many different things to list so ill say this, the game is much much better than previous hitman games for gameplay. Everything is really smooth, quick, perfect, controls are great just everything.
and graphics are a step in the right direction but nothing thats eye catching (I play on absolute max in 4K on my 980ti).
It is worse for th episodic nature, lack of difficulty, and the month by month release.

Again, ill say it, ive had NO ISSUES WITH THE ONLINE, i can see why others might have but it doesnt take long to connect to the server and there is an offline mode regardless.

Final verdict is that it is worth it for now, and im sure it will only get better. Buy the intro pack if you want to test it out without commiting, its definitely worth the money.

EDIT: funnily enough, as of loading up the game after the review, i had a little bit of a hiccup getting online. I though i should note this, even if it only set me back a couple of seconds.

reviewText:
I've been a fan of Hitman since Hitman 2. Like many others, I consider Blood money to be the best in the series, got some great memories from that game. Personally I kinda enjoyed Absolution, although you had to play it 'right' otherwise it didn't feel like a hitman game at all... too much action and gunplay, plus the AI was kinda hit and miss.

After spending my first 6 hours or so with this installment, i feel there's a return to form. This feels much more like hitman games of old, and as much as the negative reviews are because of the way in which this game has been released, it says nothing about the gameplay, which is solid.

Costumes actually work this time around and blending in to the crowd is good fun. There's lots of ways to create distractions and diversions to clear yourself a path so you rarely have to come into contact with suspicious characters. Lots of interesting ways to dispatch of your target. I'm ok with the way it's been released, it'll give me chance to get to know each level as they come out, I intend to spend a lot of time in this game so that's fine by me.

If it continues like this with future installments, i'll be happy.

Good game/10

reviewText: Finally a worthy successor to Blood Money, Hitman takes the stuff that actually worked from Absolution (i.e. a cover system) and combines them with Blood Money's core to make a fun game. The Intro pack gives you three levels, two tutorials and a story mission, Paris. The first two levels are decent sized levels, but Paris is freaking big and dense as hell, it’s like two or three Blood Money levels rolled into one. Just look at my playtime. There are plethora of ways to kill your targets and there’s a lot you can find and learn by exploring and listening in on conversations. Paris has a lot of interconnected subplots that you can completely miss out on.\n\nPeople have been complaining about terrible performance and terrible loading times, but I have had absolutely none of that running on Mid-High settings on Direct X 11 and my computer ain't all that high end. Not going to totally discount them though, so fair warning. Also if you want to unlock challenges right now you need to have a stable internet connection. Also there are bugs, the most egregious being sometimes the game doesn’t want you to drag bodies around. Pretty much any problems this game has can be fixed with patches though and IO are taking fan response into account. I'm definitely looking forward to the next level.

reviewText: This is the best example of the Hitman forumla at work. The large open sandbox style levels of Blood Money combined with the sharp controls of Absolution. There is a lot of nay-say about the fact that this is an episodic game; but any review by a steam user that complains about this, bought the game with full knowledge of the fact and thus should not complain simply on that point alone. The arguement is whether the current offering is substantial for what you paid. If you buy the intro pack alone and hate it, then you are not going to be sold by the future missions because you have experienced what Hitman has to offer in a nutshell. I have played 7 hours thus far and completed the Paris mission in 3 different ways; yet I find myself wanting to perfect it and try every possible combination. Therefore I have every confidence that the the full experience will live to its potential when it completes this year and potentially expands into 2017. I Actually I feel that the episodic nature helps the game. It encourages you to milk every possible outcome and try each mission in multiple ways where arguably if you had the full experience on launch, you'd probably blitz through it in one sitting and not take the time to explore all of the possibilities available (or even play the game a second time). This is the way that gaming is heading unfortunately, but if other titles follow by Hitman's example they will be more refined experiences in the long run. It's a slippery slope and undoubtedly a lot of companies will abuse this model, but this game is not an example of that.

reviewText:
As much as I enjoy this new entry in the Hitman series, it is really lacking in content. The deicision to release this episodically is going to hurt this game a lot! The graphics are nice, and the mechanics are very similiar to Blood Money, albeit not as deep and rewarding. It's basically a dumbed down Bloody Money and focues more on the targets, NPCs reacting to you than the other way around. Everything is scripted, and static until you interact with it. Blood Money destroys it immersion wise.

Overall it's not worth spending full price for the content they have released thus far! If you want to try and see how well it runs on your system, and if you like the gameplay you should consider the intro pack (which is the one I got), at least you won't be burned if you decide that the game is not for you, because waiting for them to release the next missions over the course of the year, would be painful to say the least.

Still there is still enjoyment to be had with the barebones content offered here, just be prepared to get bored of the same locations after a couple of hours.

WARNING: The game has an atrocious always ONLINE DRM implementation, which means if SQUARE-ENIX's servers crap out, you will be kicked out of your game session. This completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and anti-consumer feature needs to go, or I suspect they will lose many sales over this feature" alone!

OVERALL: Not worth it for the full asking price! Consider the INTRO PACK
date: and beware of the completely absurd Online DRM thrown on top of the STEAM DRM and perhaps even Denuvo... What were they thinking?!"

reviewText:
A great return to form for the Hitman series and while Episode 1 (The Intro Pack) didn't astound me, I see a bright future ahead for this Hitman entry. I absolutely loved it and I can't wait to see what they do with the rest of the season. I might not fully support the whole splitting the game into chunks ordeal but I can faithfully say that while that might suck, the game does not disappoint me. I wasn't a big fan of Absolution, but I absolutely loved Hitman 2: Silent Assassin through Hitman: Blood Money.

PROS:
-Gameplay: It's better then Absolution, feels like Blood Money to me. They took some of the best things from Absolution and applied them to this game.

-Graphics: They are absolutely fantastic. (even with some of the framerate issues)  Everyone and everything looks absolutely amazing and the people look like... actual people. My jaw hit the floor on a few occasions at how beautiful everything looked, and seeing April's content trailer made my jaw hit the floor even harder. I cannot wait to see the map for April on my computer screen.

-Audio: The world feels alive and responsive, I felt like I was in a real place during the Paris Fashion Show. I don't think the audio ever broke my immersion at any point during my playthrough of Paris.

-Music: It might not be Jesper Kyd, but it's there and what is there didn't sound like absolute crap to me. I liked it, but I would like Jesper Kyd back.

-Story: While there isn't much here, it intrigues me and I actually can't wait to see where it will go throughout the rest of the Season.

CONS: -Some framerate problems. It will probably be patched eventually but I noticed some issues during my time playing the game.

-Graphics options were greyed out for me, it again, will probably be patched but it's a current issue with the launch state of the game.

-Always online, I understand why it's like this but I don't support it.

-Poorly added in DirectX 12 support, this is my first game that I own that supports DirectX 12, and the way it's added into this game is ♥♥♥♥. I had to switch over to DirectX 11 because 12 kept crashing the tutorial level for me.

-Slightly too easy for my tastes but as I do replays I will probably tinker with the games numerous options to make it harder for myself.


Do I recommend you buy this game in it's current state?: No, if you aren't a die-hard Hitman fan.

Do I recommend you to buy this game down the line?: Yes, I'm sure by 2017 when the physical version releases a lot of these bugs will be addressed and fixed.

Did I enjoy my time with this game?: Yes, and I'm not done playing through all of it yet. I still have yet to touch Contracts Mode, Escelation Mode, and Elusive Targets (When we get one)

This review will remain updated throughout the course of 2016 as my opinions shift and change with the later levels of HITMAN™ and I will of course edit the review when I finally get around to Elusive Targets, Escalation Mode, and Contracts Mode.

Was I given a key for review by the developers?: No, of course not, I bought this game with my own hard-earned cash and so far I'm getting my moneys worth of enjoyment.

Disclaimer: This is my opinion of HITMAN™, if you do not like my opinion I will respect it, but please remember to respect mine.

reviewText:
Honestly this game wouldn't have the depth it does without it not being episodic. It gives you time to do everything and get every achievement so that you can explore, discover, and finish every possible way of completing the level.
Despite the always online DRM, and random bugs, this game is a solid 9/10.

Oh yeah and the people that think Denuvo™ is DRM. Well you're right....
But that doesn't mean Square Enix doesn't have the right to protect their intellectual property of which IO Interactive respectively owns from being stolen from them. Over all this game is probably a close second best HITMAN™ game in the series if not the best experience. This game is truly a gem. Too bad it is being misinteprated for what it really is and what the average person playing should know about the game.

My verdict is a SOLID 9/10 because this game has so much replayability and so much more gameplay then the 'average' sandbox. I totally recommend this game if you like to learn from your mistakes and figure out what to do.
This game is super rewarding especially if you turn off gameplay mechanics that make it easier so that it is much harder.
Making it worth doing something hard because it feels so good to beat something you may be stuck on for hours and hours.

Episode Verdict
Episode 1 Score:[9/10]

reviewText:
Game itself feels like a new Hitman reincarnation, with a lot of tricks to kill your target.
Finally you can freely stalk your prey without any worthless disguise system, when every single NPC on the map reacts to your disguise like you're wearing some kind of Disco ball with projectors on your head.
Non-linear maps, free sandbox experience, what else do you want from a Hitman game?
Also, that disguise system from Absolution got redacted and now only chiefs of staff can recognize you in a crowd, this type of NPC is marked as a threat so you can easily evade them.
A lot of people are complaining about Opportunity System which can be turned off in options if you so desire, so I don't really see much of a problem here.

The main prblem with this game is that it has very poor performance, but that's not really a problem for me, cuz i got PS4. But for everyone else I feel sorry and wish developers would release a few patches.

As a new Hitman game it's mechanics are good and interesting, fans of the series won't be dissapointed I hope.

You should not purchase this game right now, it's a waste of your time and money. You should wait until they fix the game. Posts about performances are not rare, it's a very big issue that IO Interactive doesn't seem to give a damn.

I want to play this game with a solid framerate (getting under 30 fps with this render is a shame) and without scripted events who make the game such easy. I will edit my review if they change this but I have no hope regarding the future since the performances are not even adress in any of the release patchs.

reviewText:
First in case you haven't noticed, this game is being released in episodes throughout the year. There's 3 training levels and 1 main level out currently. If you're not a completionist then I can't recommend this for you. Out of the small amount of content that is currently available I've gotten 19 hours of play out of it which is more than most full campaigns I've ran through. The Paris level that is currently available is a fairly large place to explore. I also turned off the hints to get more playtime out of it. I think the graphics look fairly good and they certainly put detail into the setting. There are plenty of ways to kill the targets that you'd expect from a Hitman game.

The game requires an internet connection to access all of the features and if you lose connection during a session you'll be booted the the main menu. I've only had this happen once. Otherwise the game runs extremely smooth for me.

I already like this installment more than Absolution and if you don't mind waiting on levels to be released throughout the year then I recommend the game.

Edit 1: The Sapienza map got released along with bug fixes. The game runs even better now and the second level is massive to explore. The newest level also brings new items to loadout with. I also like that when you unlock the new items you can use them on the old level.

CPU - i7-4790K
GPU - GTX980
32GB RAM
Windows 10 OS

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the old Hitman games, and beat (almost) all of them many times. I got full Silent Assassin status on every mission in Hitman 2 and Contracts, and I loved every second of Blood Money. Absolution I beat once, and while it was a decent game, it lacked a lot of the things I really loved about the older Hitman games. So how does this new one stack up?
It is great!
It feels more like the older games, while also adding some of the good additions of Absolution. I did turn off everything regarding Opportunities and Instinct though, so not sure how those work in the game, but the fact that you can turn off all of that if you want is a great thing.
As of this writing I have only done the main Paris mission twice and made one Contract, and I can see myself playing this a lot. If the rest of the episodes are this good then this will be the best Hitman game out there.

reviewText: While I don't like the online requirement and I have had about 4 crashes in the game in about 6 hours gameplay I still want to give a positive review, while there are things that needs to be fixed I don't think this game deserves all the hate it has got. People also complain that there is only 1 mission, but there is really 3 main missions that can be completed in multiple ways + a lot of contracts and other modes that increase the replayability even more. For an intro pack" I think there is well enough content in my opinion.\n\nBut on to the actual game. I have been a big fan of the Hitman series since the start and have played every game since then. While I don't feel like this edition of Hitman really brings that much new to the formula it still feels very polished and the gameplay is still as interesting now as it was in the first game. The one thing that have always impressed the most in any Hitman game is the levels
date: they are often huge and very believable with tons of npc:s roaming around and paths and things you can explore that take many playthrough to discover. The Paris mission here really shines in those areas and is probably one of the best in the series in scope and complexity (The Hotel mission from the first game is still my favorite though)\n\nThe biggest differance to the game this time I would say is the "challanges". Every level has a big roster of challanges to be completed
recommended: most often killing your target in very specific and interesting ways. My biggest gripe with the game however is that there is no difficulty slider this time

reviewText:
11/10, blew a man's face up with a mine in the toilet basin he was throwing up in.

But seriously, the gameplay is great, I wasn't expecting to like this game as much as I do, especially because of the episodic release, but it's actually quite nice, it gives you more time to complete a mission and all it's challenges / contracts before the next one comes out. The performance is also really good as far as I can tell, I'm using a Radeon Strix Fury and AMD FX-8350, and I can run Hitman on Max setting 60 fps, 1080p, even in the areas wih hundreds of people.

Hitman does also have 'Always online DRM' although the servers are faultless in my experience, so it won't always be Square Enix's fault if you disconnect. I know it would be better for people if Hitman didn't have the DRM, but Square have done all they can to make sure it doesn't interfere with the game.

reviewText: I think this game is getting too much unjust criticism. The devlopers did not lie to you. You knew this was going to be an episodic title, just like the critically acclaimed Life is Strange. You knew there was going to be one main level at launch. They said they were focusing on nonlinearity a la Blood Money, and they did. The performance is very good considering the game's visual fidelity - Grand Theft Auto V performs worse than this on my GTX 970 (I know GTAV's world is larger than Hitman's, but anyone who knows how open worlds are procedurally generated knows this isn't much of an excuse). The always online DRM, while I may not agree with it, does not cause me any problems playing through the game, and I have not had any disconnections. The lack of challenge progression in offline mode doesn't affect me personally, as I think it's fun to play a Hitman game with only the standard equipment, and try your hardest not to use anything but the fibre wire. Other players may disagree, and for those players, it needs fixing, but it does not affect my personal enjoyment of the game.\n\nAll in all, the developers worked hard on this Hitman game, and it shows. It feels just as good, if not better than Blood Money and the developers were honest to us from the get-go. For $15 you get a tutorial level, 2 sandboxy tutorial missions (that you can still complete in different ways), one fully fleshed out campaign level, and several alternate targets you can choose to assassinate in each level. And if you payed $60 and want more content from the get-go... be patient, man. As I said before, everyone knew this was going to be episodic. Life is Strange released episodes 2 to 3 months apart with delays, and no one really criticized it. Additional Hitman levels are scheduled to release monthly, and you WILL get what you payed for, but in the meantime, maybe do something besides play video games? Get a job, spend time with your family, create your OWN project? There's a lot you can do while you wait, and each time a new episode comes out, you can make your playthrough of that new episode your zen time" for the month. If you just want to bum rush the entire story in 24 hours
date: WAIT. BE PATIENT. You will get to. That is all. Have a good one."

reviewText:
Cosa dire...a me personalmente piace.
Si, è pur vero che c'è da attendere per i contenuti e questa cosa è un po una rottura, anche se l'attesa sembrerebbe ben ripagata.
La giocabilità torna la classica dei vecchi titoli con l'aggiunta dei movimenti di Absolution che ti danno modo di uccidere e non i modi differenti a seconda di come si preferisce giocare.
Sicuramente l'elemento vincente sono le mappe. Bellissime!
Per chi è rimasto forse un po deluso da parigi, (che per quanto possa sembrare piccola è comunque un bel luogo da esplorare e studiare) Sapienza sicuramente darà più spirito al gameplay. Enorme, magnifica, curatissima nei dettagli. Ti vien quasi più voglia di vivertela che giocarci quasi.
Molti potrebbero lamentarsi del fatto che vengono mostrate scorciatoie per completare gli obbiettivi, ma fortunatamente sono disattivabili e si può procedere per la maniera desiderata.
Bello anche che per ogni travestimento c'è sempre da stare attenti nel caso ci dovessero essere persone che ti potrebbero riconoscere, e che se scoperti ci si può nascondere non solo in cassonetti ma anche tra la folla o mimetizzarsi con l'ambiente leggendo un giornale su una panchina. Insomma...tanta roba.
Per fare un esempio, sapienza se si conosce come mappa si potrebbe finire subito. Ma io me la sono goduta in quasi 4 ore di gioco.
Spero che anche se molto random come recensione sia servita a darvi qualche dritta. Potrei scrivere di meglio ma sono pigro.
E comunque è un 8/10 per me.

reviewText: Enjoying it quite a bit, although as I never played any entry of the franchise, I can only gauge Hitman on its own merit. reviewText:
Oeiginally hated that this game was going to release epicodically.  I've now actually come to appreciate it.  Instead of just doing what I would noramlly do, and blow through the campaign, I only have one bit to play at a time.  The two levels available now are both unique and challenging.  I've spent more time on these levels than I have in any other game of a similar sturcture, and I've played Hitman since the original.  This game is super fun, and it's the perfect game to play for a relaxing experience.
Some small performance issues on my AMD 7950, and graphics drivers stop responding on my nvidia 980m.  So it does need some polish I feel, but it's not bad enough to be unplayable.
The game is a worthy addition to the Hitman franchise.  Has the best elements from the newer titles, but when I play the game, I feel like I'm taken back to my playstyle of Hitman 2, or contracts.  Feels good.
Don't let the mixed reviews convince you to pass this one up.  If you are a fan of any Hitman game ever, buy this game.

reviewText:
This game has problems, and it's certainly not perfect, but I really enjoy it and I think other people will too.

One of the things I especially like about this game is the way it punishes you for rampant violence. Pulling out a gun and shooting someone in broad daylight almost never ends well, simply because you can't survive more than a few gunshots in a row. That feels more realistic to me than being able to mow down countless civilians without consequence.

I also like that some objectives cannot be achieved without ingenuity or nonviolent methods. For example, in order to destroy the virus in Sapienza, you have to reach the lab (which is heavily guarded and has many keycard-locked access points) and find a way to destroy it without getting immediately spotted by the numerous guards (whether that be with a kill switch, manually, via stalactite, from a distance with a gun, or with a penetrating sniper rifle [though that can't be used until Sapienza has been mastered]). To reach the auction in Paris (almost certainly a necessity in order to kill Dalia Margolis), you have to find one of four specific and rare disguises, a secret invitation, or a hidden access route. I like the way the game makes you plan out your actions and try to learn people's habits. The always online component is annoying and sometimes buggy, and my computer isn't fully equipped to run the game at a good framerate, but I still think it's pretty great.
